text: Story prompt: 13-year-old Max was headed to a friend’s house. As someone who can’t drive yet, he uses a ride-sharing app to get from one place to another. On this day, however, he ended up sharing a ride with a stranger. 13 years old as well, she was dressed fashionably and had an air of popularity to her. Someone who definitely went out with friends more often than others. According to the app, her destination was a large shopping mall, closer than Max’s friend’s house, thought pretty far away. It would take about 30 minutes to get to the mall. In the meantime, Max, who was never one to initiate conversation, kept to himself. Still, 30 minutes was gonna take a while. “So… mall, huh?”, awkwardly asked Max to start a conversation. “Yeah.”, was the response she gave him. Doesn’t seem like she was interested. Why would she? Everyone’s a stranger in the car. This was gonna be a long ride. Still, it didn’t seem like she was completely cold and distant. After a few minutes had passed, Max opened up with, “Hanging out with a friend today. Thinking you’re doing the same?” The girl responded, “Yeah. Probably just gonna go window shopping.”, while on her phone. “Got any other plans after that?”, asked Max. Even she was surprised to answer him so casually, saying, “We got basketball practice today at 4.” Max replied, “Oh, cool. I had a feeling you were the sporty type too.” It didn’t take long for the seemingly awkward boy and the seemingly disinterested girl to actually engage in long conversations. It didn’t even register to them that they were already at the mall. “I’m Max, by the way.” The girl replied, “My name’s Suzanna. Or Suzie, but whatever. It was nice talkin’ to you, Max.”, just before closing the door and going inside the mall. As the car began to head to his friend’s house, Max couldn’t help but think to himself, “I just had a good conversation with a stranger. Pretty, too.”

text: EmbedDataInBMP[bmpFile_, dataFile_, outputFile_] := Module[{imageData, dataToEmbed, extendedData, modifiedImageData, outputStream, success, dataSizeBytes}, imageData = BinaryReadList[bmpFile]; dataToEmbed = Import[dataFile, “Text”, CharacterEncoding -> “WindowsCyrillic”]; dataToEmbed = ToCharacterCode[dataToEmbed, “WindowsCyrillic”]; If[Length[dataToEmbed] == 0, MessageDialog[“Нет данных для встраивания.”]; Return[False]]; dataSizeBytes = IntegerDigits[Length[dataToEmbed], 256, 4]; extendedData = Join[dataToEmbed, ConstantArray[0, 16 - Mod[Length[dataToEmbed], 16]]]; modifiedImageData = Join[Take[imageData, 54], dataSizeBytes, extendedData, Drop[imageData, 58 + Length[extendedData]]]; outputStream = OpenWrite[outputFile, BinaryFormat -> True]; BinaryWrite[outputStream, modifiedImageData, “Byte”]; Close[outputStream]; success = FileExistsQ[outputFile]; If[success, MessageDialog[“Внедрение данных выполнено успешно.”]; True, MessageDialog[“Не удалось встроить данные.”]; False]] ;; bmpPath = “C:\Users\Я\Pictures\stego.bmp”; dataPath = “C:\Users\Я\Documents\data.txt”; outputBmpPath = “C:\Users\Я\Pictures\stego+эцп.bmp”; If[FileExistsQ[bmpPath] && FileExistsQ[dataPath], If[EmbedDataInBMP[bmpPath, dataPath, outputBmpPath], If[FileExistsQ[outputBmpPath], extractedFilePath = ExtractDataFromBMP[outputBmpPath]; MessageDialog["Данные извлечены в: " <> extractedFilePath]], MessageDialog[“Не удалось встроить.”] ] ]; обьясни алгоритм кода

text: Format this: Her name was Sasha. Though we had gone to high school together, we were from two different crowds and never really knew each other. We ended up sharing a few classes together our first year of college, and that's when we began to talk. After sitting next to me in one of our classes, she noticed how smart I was and would often ask me for help with anything she didn't understand. Next thing I knew she was sitting next to me in every class we had together. I couldn't believe my luck. I had a major crush on her back in high school, but never had the balls to talk to her. Now she was asking me to spend more time with her outside of class to help tutor her, and I couldn't have been happier to do so. I love getting so much one on one time with her. She was super sweet, completely different from the popular mean girl persona she had in high school. She was always so giggly around me and always finding excuses to put her hands on my arm or shoulder. I couldn't help but feel she was flirting with me, but I still didn't have the nerve to ask her out. We maintained our friendship for the whole year. She would often drag me out to major parties that I never would've been invited to and always did her best to try to include me in conversations and pull me out of my shell a little. She never made any major moves to solidify whether or not she was in to me or just saw me as a really good friend. It got to a point where almost every time we hung out I was waiting for her to say something about how I feel like a brother to her or something, but that never happened. She just continued to confuse me and feed me mixed signals. Summer came along and we parted ways with a hug, and she said she couldn't wait to see me again at the end of summer break, so that felt somewhat promising. I spent all summer thinking about her, missing all the time that I had grown used to spending with her. I watched summer tik away slowly as I impatiently waited for school to start back up again. When the first day of the new year started I saw Sasha quickly making her way towards me. "Oh my God!" She yelled happily. "I'm so glad you're back! The summer was kinda boring without my cute little pet by my side!" Pet.. I wasn't sure how to take that. She did say I was cute.. What kind of message was she trying to give here? I brushed it off and gave her a big hug. We went off to find a quiet spot and she told me all about her summer and how she wished I could've been there with her. Our relationship was starting to feel like it was in a better place than when summer started. Near the end of October she told me that there was going to be this killer costume party and she wanted me to go with her. She was going as a witch and asked if I would be her peasant slave. I thought it was a weird request, but at the same time, this was sounding very much like a couples costume. At this point I had already developed very strong feeling for her and would do whatever it took for an opportunity to win her over, so I happily agreed. The night of the party she came to pick me up. The party was a decent ways off campus, tucked away in the middle of nowhere, so as to avoid cops coming to shut down the party. I was pretty excited. She made for one hot witch, and I didn't care if my costume was kind of demeaning because it made her so happy that we could go together. When we got there I noticed that there weren't a lot of familiar faces, but the party was bumpin either way so I didn't care nor think much of it. As the night carried on she drug me around with her everywhere, showing off our costumes, often joking about how she planned on taking me back to her lair for her dinner. She kept handing me beer after beer, I assumed trying to get me to loosen up. I'm not the most social person ever and can get kind of shy in groups. Her plan was working however. The more I drank the easier it was to open up and enjoy myself. It had started getting late and a lot of people had already made their way home. There were still a few stragglers, ourselves included. She took me by the hand and led me into a big empty room. She turned to look at me and grabbed me by the hand. "You've been a good little peasant slave," she said with a giggle and a wink. "Now, being the generous witch that I am, I'll grant you one free wish! What'll it be!?" I was heavily intoxicated, and as I looked at her gorgeous face, only one thing came to mind. "I just want to be yours forever." As soon as I said it I froze up. I hadn't thought before I spoke, and now it was all out there. I guess now I would finally get my definitive answer. A smile formed on her black lips. "What would you do to prove that you're worthy to be mine?" Was she serious? Did I actually stand a chance!? "I would do anything your heart desires," I said as sweetly as my drunken self could muster. She reached into her purse and pulled out salt and a candle. I was confused but just watched as she made a ring of salt on the floor and lit the candle in the middle of it. "I will give you the ultimate test then," she said stepping out of the circle after lighting the candle. "Step inside the circle." I did as she said and she started to mumble words I couldn't understand.

"I would do anything your heart desires," I said as sweetly as my drunken self could muster. She reached into her purse and pulled out salt and a candle. I was confused but just watched as she made a ring of salt on the floor and lit the candle in the middle of it. "I will give you the ultimate test then," she said stepping out of the circle after lighting the candle. "Step inside the circle." I did as she said and she started to mumble words I couldn't understand.

text: Byline: Nazish Imran, Aateqa Hashmi and Ahad Imran KEYWORDS: Artificial Intelligence, Child Mental Health, ChatGPT, Open AI, Mental Illness. "ChatGPT puts the power of AI in everyone's hand." - Fredrick Godin ChatGPT is making a significant impact in everyone's life around the globe, including younger population. More than 25% of the population of the world is under the age of 14. Mental Health in children and adolescents is a pressing public health issue. The World Health Organization estimates that nearly 20% of these children suffer from psychiatric problems.1 With huge treatment gap in Child and adolescent mental health care especially in low and middle-income countries and increase need for psychiatric diagnosis and treatment services, artificial intelligence (AI) and digital interfaces are emerging as viable alternatives for reducing this gap. The ChatGPT (Chat-Generative Pre-Trained Transformer) and other AI-based chatbot's ability to generate human-quality responses can help in making mental health services accessible and affordable.2 Chat-GPT is an AI-based language model which uses natural language processing (NLP) and conversational AI to help mental health professionals deliver more personalized and effective mental health support. This is possible because the system is powered by a machine learning algorithm, trained using large dataset of clinical interactions in healthcare. ChatGPT can support child and adolescent mental health by supporting physicians as well as patients and families in various ways. Benefits for Mental Health Practitioners: A resource for Mental health clinicians: ChatGPT could be used to analyze a child and adolescent's language text for patterns and correlations that can reveal underlying mental health issues. It can help clinicians in providing quick access to assessment tools, new evidence-based treatment options and best clinical practices for managing common child and adolescent mental health problems. It can also flag potential drug interactions and help in reducing prescription errors, while saving clinician's time.3 Enhance Proactive treatment adjustments: ChatGPT can assess intensity of negative cognitive distortions by analyzing patients' language patterns in real time, which alongside clues from mental health state examination may help clinicians to improve diagnostic accuracy, determine early treatment response and enhance proactive adjustments in treatment.4,5 Extracting Information from Large sets of Data: Chat GPT can use its vast database of language to generate reports and summaries from large sets of data, such as patient interviews. This could assist mental health practitioners to diagnose children and adolescents and develop personalized treatments quickly and accurately. Lab reports, imaging results and any other relevant information can also be extracted quickly from patients records.5 Facilitation of Communication: ChatGPT can facilitate communication between young patients and mental health professionals by precise and swift translation of medical jargon and technical terminologies due to its advanced language processing capabilities. It thus allows clinicians to help engage children and adolescents in their management plan and better understand their diagnosis and treatment options. Integration of ChatGPT enabled apps in healthcare devices: ChatGPT enabled apps and its potential integration in healthcare devices such as smart wearables, and other monitoring devices is one of the most exciting developments and can have a potential future role in offering real time insight in child and adolescent health status . Teaching and Training in child mental health: ChatGPT can be effective tool in medical education, Child and adolescent mental health teaching and training by identifying gaps in knowledge, for content creation, producing high quality engaging content at scale, helping in lesson planning and assessments.6 This can be very cost effective in improving awareness of child and adolescent mental health amongst schoolteachers and allied pediatric health professionals. Reduction in Occupational stress: By providing 'short cuts' for time consuming, but menial tasks, ChatGPT can help to extend child mental health professionals time and resources, and potentially reduce occupational stress. Benefits for Patients and Families: Easy access to information about Mental health issues: Children and adolescents can better comprehend and look after their mental health by using ChatGPT to know more about mental illnesses, various coping methods, and treatment choices Easy access to mental health support: Stigma, financial constraints, poor access to services and reluctance to seek traditional therapies due to cultural and societal myths are some of the barriers preventing children and adolescents from receiving mental healthcare they need.7 ChatGPT and AI apps can provide children and adolescents with a non-judgmental and accessible means for mental health care. A research showed "Woebot" to be effective in reducing depression among college students after just two weeks of therapy modeled after cognitive behavioral therapy and was considered as empathetic too.8 In another ongoing project, The WHO Sustainable Technology for Adolescents and youth to Reduce Stress (STARS) led to development of a chatbot that delivers transdiagnostic cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) content. Conversational pattern in ChatGPT can mimic real time therapist especially for people with social anxiety disorder. Role in crisis: ChatGPT can be used to triage patients by enquiring about their symptoms and relevant medical and past history to determine the severity and urgency of their condition. ChatGPT's ability to provide 24/7 support ensuring constant availability of digital mental health can be particularly helpful for people in crisis. It can help control suicidal ideation or panic attacks when access to professional is not possible as they can get support from online apps. In case of suicidal thinking referenced directly in ChatGPT, it provides contact information for the Suicide and Crisis helplines. Help in Stress reduction: ChatGPT can also be a practical tool for youngsters stressed with time management and organization. by breaking down complicated assignments into manageable steps. This can assist in managing anxiety linked with feeling overwhelmed. Limitation of Human Biases: Risk of bias even subconsciously may occur during human interactions in therapy. ChatGPT may help in supporting mental health of children and adolescents, who may be concerned about their therapist judging them or who are unwilling to talk to a therapist about sensitive issues or sharing confidential information. Limitations: Ben Buchanan and Andrew Imbrue argued in their Book "The New Fire War, Peace, and Democracy in the Age of AI" that "AI is like fire; if we control it, it can become a source of power; otherwise, it can become a source of destruction." Despite the advantages of ChatGPT, it is unwise to dismiss the limitations and potential concerns regarding AI technologies.5,6 ChatGPT is trained on humanannotated data which is prone to bias. The model then identifies patterns in this data and subsequently may also shows bias in some scenarios. Although ChatGPT can provide evidence-based information, it cannot diagnose or advise a management plan exactly tailored to a child and adolescent's specific needs. A lot of complex factors influencing child and adolescent mental health like socioeconomic status, educational and cultural factors, family dynamics cannot be addressed by ChatGPT. ChatGPT, if not prepared with data from authentic and reliable sites, may be potentially harmful to children and adolescents with psychiatric problems by providing inappropriate and wrong advice. One of the main limitations is deficiency of human like understanding in AI technologies. In managing a child's mental health conditions, therapeutic alliance between child and therapist is very important and is built through attunement, positive regard, and non-verbal communications, where ChatGPT falls short. It may not be sensitive to non-verbal communication or subtle signals of crisis by children and adolescents facing mental health issues like suicidal and homicidal risks. The inability to detect such warning signs and ask relevant questions to assess safety may lead to catastrophic outcomes. ChatGPT may not always identify when a child and adolescent require more assistance. Furthermore, Chatbots are also not capable of providing the same degree of emotional support as a trained therapist. However, they can be a helpful supplement to traditional therapy.3,5 Confidentiality and privacy are crucial factors in mental health support for children and adolescents, and it is essential to ensure that users' information is kept secure. Any child or adolescent utilizing ChatGPT for their psychiatric issues is likely to share sensitive personal and family details, making them potentially vulnerable in cases of breach of confidentiality. American Psychiatric Association (APA) in view of the urgent need to regulate AI-based tools, has created a digital psychiatry task force to evaluate and monitor AI and mental health-related apps for their efficacy, safety, and potential to provide mental health care. CONCLUSION To conclude, ChatGPT can revolutionize child and adolescent mental healthcare by acting as an effective assisting tool. But it would be unwise and impractical to suggest that it can replace human clinical judgment entirely. Safe and responsible usage is the key to make the best use of this assisting tool for mental health promotion in this vulnerable age groups. Grant support and financial disclosures: None.

text: For my book the following is how I wrote up the lab reports:ABSTRACT This report outlines the progress of ongoing experiments conducted at The Playground of Higher Consciousness during the second week. The focus of our research is to evaluate the impact of environmental and nutritional adjustments on the brain function of participants. Our primary subject, Uma, has demonstrated unprecedented brain level production across all monitored activities, prompting a dietary adjustment to pot pie-flavored smoothies, excluding roast beef flavor, to maintain cerebral health. Continuous observation of Uma, including during personal activities, is addressed with ethical considerations, assigning Dr. Kawalsky the responsibility of oversight to ensure participant privacy and dignity. This report also notes varied brain production levels in other subjects—Lance showing a slight increase, Byron a decrease, and Twink's levels remaining constant, suggesting a potential adjustment in medication. Deborah, showing minimal brain activity, is considered for an incubation strategy to enhance brain frequencies. Additionally, the report suggests integrating communal activities and wellness treatments to further study their effects on brain function. WEEKLY REPORT BY DR. RUBY ALLEN The second week of experimentation at The Playground of Higher Consciousness has been significantly marked by the outstanding performance of our subject, Uma. Her contributions across various stations have set new records for brain level production, highlighting the effectiveness of our environmental and nutritional interventions. Subject Uma’s Progress: In response to Uma's exceptional results, we have decided to alter her dietary regimen to include pot pie-flavored smoothies, deliberately omitting the roast beef variant to diversify her nutritional intake and potentially stimulate further cerebral activity. To ensure comprehensive monitoring, Uma will be observed continuously, a decision that has raised ethical considerations regarding privacy during personal care activities. Dr. Kawalsky has agreed to assume responsibility for this sensitive aspect of the study, with measures taken to respect Uma's privacy and dignity. Other Subjects' Performance: • Lance: Exhibited a slight increase in brain production levels, suggesting positive responsiveness to the current experimental conditions. • Byron: Demonstrated a minor decrease in brain production, warranting closer examination of his environmental and nutritional influences. • Twink: Showed no change in brain production levels, indicating a potential need for medication reassessment to optimize cognitive function. • Deborah: Reported minimal brain activity, prompting consideration for an innovative incubation approach aimed at "cooking" her brain frequencies to enhance output. Her diet will be restricted to breakfast-themed smoothies, with a focus on flapjacks with maple syrup and soy chorizo flavors. Additional Interventions: To further explore the impact of environmental and social factors on brain function, the group will engage in more collective activities within the Tee Pee setting, complemented by pedicure and manicure sessions. This holistic approach aims to not only study the direct effects on brain production but also to foster a sense of community and well-being among participants. Conclusion: The findings from week two underscore the complexity of brain function and the potential of targeted environmental and nutritional interventions to enhance cognitive output. Continuous observation and adaptive strategies will be critical in maximizing the potential of each subject while upholding the highest standards of ethical research practices.

text: make this sound better "Technology has always been an interest of mine ever since my parents bought me a Playstation 2 when I was only 5 years old. I knew technology was going to be what I would want to be involved with when I would get older. Here I am today, wanting to pursue a career in IT and make that dream that I had when I was a kid to become a reality. During my time in the military, I did not know if I wanted to stay in the military as an electrician or pursue a career that interests me more. I ended up leaving the military to pursue a career in technology. However, I did not know what interest me more; Computer Science or Information Technology. I tried computer science and I loved programming, but something was missing from the Computer Science curriculum that aligns with my interest in technology. That would be the interpersonal and communication skills that moves alongside with technology. That is when I decided that I would be more interested in majoring in Information Technology and Informatics. I would like to major in Information Technology and Informatics to further my knowledge and interest in technology while being taught by the best professors that Rutgers has to offer. I hope to learn more about cyber security and data management where my interests in IT reside in DevOps engineering, data analytics, security analyst, and data warehousing. My method of getting to one of these points is by following the guided pathways for both cyber security and data management that Rutgers University has to offer."

text: write an article out of this press release: -- RELEASE EMBARGOED APRIL 28, 2023, AT 12 PM NOON-- Olympian clean seas activist Neil Agius attempts world-first open water swim. The 100 Mile Swim will be his greatest challenge yet. PALMA DE MALLORCA, SPAIN – On WEDNESDAY, April 27, 2023. Neil Agius, ultra-endurance athlete and world record holder, on Friday officially announced the 100 Mile Swim, a world-first record attempt in the longest non-stop, unassisted, current neutral, open water sea swim ever undertaken. The launch took place Friday, April 28, at 12:00 at the Palma International Boat Show & Superyacht Village, where Agius shared his vision for the challenge and his reasons for undertaking it. The 100 Mile Swim will see Agius attempt to swim from Mallorca around the west coast of Ibiza touching land on the eastern coast of Ibiza, covering approximately 160km, in open water. The swim will test Agius's endurance, strength, and mental resilience. A former Olympian and current world record holder in another category of swim, Agius is no stranger to pushing his limits. However, the 100 Mile Swim represents his most ambitious challenge yet. Speaking ahead of the launch, Agius said, "The 100 Mile Swim is not just about setting a world record. More importantly, it is about highlighting the problem of pollution and pollutants in the seas and oceans.” Media Contact: Ivan Martin <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS> <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_PHONE_NUMBER> The 100 Mile Swim will take place in the summer of 2023 during a brief weather window that begins at the end of June. Agius has been training intensively for months to prepare for the challenge. He is supported by a team of around 25 volunteers and professionals made up of medics, swim observers, navigators, skippers and crew, motivators, media, and a nutritionist, who will ensure that he remains safe and healthy throughout the swim. The launch of the 100 Mile Swim is expected to generate significant interest from the global media and supporters. Agius's previous successful world record attempts have been covered by major news outlets around the world, and the 100 Mile Swim is likely to attract even more attention. The swim will also raise awareness for ocean conservation and the urgent need to conserve our precious marine ecosystem, causes very close to Neil's heart. The 100 Mile swim is supported by the Mallorca Preservation Foundation as well as Neil's own NGO Wave of Change Malta, Ocibar Marinas and the Palma International Boat Show as well as being proudly sponsored by Atlas Insurance and Visit Malta. The Palma International Boat Show & Superyacht Village provides the perfect backdrop for the launch of the 100 Mile Swim. The event is one of the most prestigious boat shows in the world and attracts thousands of visitors each year. Agius will have the opportunity to speak to a global audience about his vision for the challenge and the impact he hopes it will have. The launch of the 100 Mile Swim is set to be a historic moment for endurance swimming and a significant milestone for Agius personally. With just a few months to go until the swim, Agius and his team are ready to take on this epic challenge and make history. Media Contact: Ivan Martin <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS> <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_PHONE_NUMBER> --- ENDS ---

text: Absolutely, let's recap the essence of the Teddy Tint campaign: Campaign Objective: The primary goal of the Teddy Tint campaign is to introduce and promote Maybelline Superstay Teddy Tint, a makeup product designed to offer a Natural Effortless look with great color, long-lasting wear, and a light and comfortable feel for both lips and cheeks. Consumer Needs Addressed: COLORS: Providing a wide range of vibrant and appealing colors. CLEAN (No mess, Long-lasting): Ensuring clean and long-lasting application. CARE (Light + Comfortable): Offering a comfortable and lightweight makeup experience. Iconic Character - Teddy Soft: Teddy Soft, a playful pink teddy bear, serves as the campaign's iconic character. Teddy Soft embodies qualities like cuteness, youthfulness, fluffiness, comfort, playfulness, and huggability. He is used to create an emotional connection with the product and the campaign's values. Campaign Approach: The campaign strategically leverages Teddy Soft's attributes to connect with the audience emotionally. Teddy Soft enhances the appeal of the product and serves as a memorable and meaningful brand symbol. Activation Strategy: The campaign includes multiple phases, starting with a teaser phase, online engagement, virtual events, and culminating in a highly anticipated on-ground activation. These phases aim to generate excitement, foster a connection with the audience, and promote the product effectively. Overall Message: The campaign seeks to introduce Maybelline Superstay Teddy Tint in a way that resonates with consumers seeking makeup products that meet their demands for vibrant colors, clean and long-lasting application, and comfortable wear. Teddy Soft serves as a relatable and heartwarming character that reinforces the campaign's values of softness, kindness, compassion, and hope. In essence, the campaign uses the endearing Teddy Soft to convey the product's qualities, creating a unique and emotionally resonant experience for consumers.

text: 2.1 Human AAA tissue samples RNA sequence Five human AAA tissues and their adjacent normal aortic tissue were collected for sequencing. Human AAA samples were obtained with the approval of the Ethics Committee of the Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University. The diagnosis of AAA was confirmed by computed tomography angiography prior to surgery in all patients. Adjacent normal aortic tissue and AAA samples were obtained from 5 patients with elevated IgE who underwent open surgery. All tissue samples were frozen in liquid nitrogen immediately after resection and stored at −80°C until further processing. Detailed information of patients was shown in Table 1. Quality control, sequencing and further analysis of AAA tissue samples were carried out.

Adjacent normal aortic tissue and AAA samples were obtained from 5 patients with elevated IgE who underwent open surgery. All tissue samples were frozen in liquid nitrogen immediately after resection and stored at −80°C until further processing. Detailed information of patients was shown in Table 1. Quality control, sequencing and further analysis of AAA tissue samples were carried out.

She answered all my questions swiftly and correctly, moreover she had a maximum score during the semester so I confidently proved her knowledge to be excellent (5 points out of 5). But even before that she was highly recommended to me by the Machine learning course’s lecturer: she was described as a hardworking student with great communication skills, eager to evolve in the field . So in autumn 2023 I gladly agreed to become her thesis supervisor at the base department of Intelligent Systems. Moreover, she got high scores in all other subjects of the base department(such as Deep learning, Bayesian Model selection, Mathematical Forecasting methods), so I wasn’t surprised when she decided to apply to the Université Grenoble Alpes. Therefore, without a doubt, I recommend Anna Remizova for admission and hope that she can develop her passion for Machine Learning into a career and further refine her skills."

text: Write minimum of 1000 words detailed Research Methodology With subtitles Goal, research design, data collection, sampling and data analysis Use the following as the central idea Assessment of the Role of Leadership and Leadership Styles on Agricultural Inputs Production, Supply, and Distribution in Ethiopia Although agriculture is the dominant sector in Ethiopia, crop productivity remains at a very low level largely because of low level of input utilization. The use of these inputs is very low compared to other countries regardless of being a high agenda of the government for decades. ” It has been an agenda on one hand and poor implementation and commitment, on the other hand” For instance, less than 20% of agricultural land is covered by quality seed and the average chemical fertilizer use is only about 26 kg/ha (World Bank, 2014). The use of improved cattle breed is also less than 2% while Agricultural Inputs coverage at national level is below 20%. The low use of these inputs is actually reflected in the low productivity of the agricultural sector. It is not uncommon also to see excess stock of these inputs in the country portraying inefficiency at the operational system particularly due to promotion and timely distribution

text: make the following better: "Into to Credit Rover The purpose of credit rover is to systematically search the IG market for relative value ideas and flag them to PMs/traders/analysts who can apply their judgement to filter further for actionable ideas. It is a tool designed to enable FIG to generate new sources of alpha within the funds, a one-stop shop for Relative Value (RV) - for PMs, Credit analysts and Traders, a centralized warehouse for all the data needed to make investment decisions, and a common place for Research and Trading to signal trade ideas and discuss them. Credit Rover is part of a bigger platform called the Insights Platform. It aims to enable efficient market insights through intelligent data aggregation, interactive modules, and configurable alerts. Over time, the Insights platform should expand to support additional applications, especially given the volume of proprietary information we have—which grows every day. RV & Signal RV stands for Relative Value. It is a quantitative analytical approach and is a systematic way to address the fundamental question: what’s expensive and what’s cheap? It allows us to identify relative misvaluations between and among securities, and if they improve the quality of the predictions we make about the future richening and cheapening of these securities. Credit RoVer uses mainly price adjusted OAS to generate relative value signals. The aim is to have one centralized place for all data RV everyone would agree upon. Curve fitting is needed as the starting point for relative value. It allows us to judge which bonds are cheap or rich on an issuer's curve, as well as generate a long history of 5y, 10y, 30y, etc. points to make apples to apples comparisons across issuers for the purpose of relative value. In RoVer, what we effectively try to do is fit thousands of curves automatically and every day. Each issuer or benchmark has a specific curve. Not time efficient to build it out manually for each of them. Curve fitting can be used as an aid for data visualization (term structure), to infer values of a function where no data is available (new issues), and to summarize the relationship among two or more variables (maturity and model OAS). What we effectively do here is generate signals for the desk that help them narrow down potential opportunities to capture alpha. In RoVer, all signals have mean reversion as an underpinning assumption. There are two types of signals, one is spread/standard RV, which focus on CUSIP vs curve signal; the other is regression RV, which illustrates curve vs curve signal. Both signals are generated based on price adjusted OAS. Spread RV looks at distance of latest value of a specific point w.r.t. mean of that same point over a specific window. Each CUSIP has 10 different options of benchmark curves, either issuer curve, or 9 other benchmarks consisting of combination of sector and ratings. This method is typically used on the Bond Selection Page. For example, the graph below looks at AAPL CUSIPs against AAPL issuer curve. The spread to curve (STC) is called the residual. We then take all STC/residuals from AAPL and find their mean. The RV signal/z-score is expressed is expressed in number of standard deviations away from mean. If the latest value is below mean, spread is considered expensive, and the RV signal is negative. If above mean, spread is considered cheap, and the RV signal is positive. Always with mean reversion as a base case. Regression RV look at how the spread of a specific point on a fitted curve compares with the same point on the benchmark curve historically. This method is shown under ‘RV Z Score’ on the Issuer Selection and Forecasting page. Taking AAPL as an example, the spread between the AAPL issuer curve and the Technology A and Above curve is the spread to benchmark (STB). We take all STB and find their mean. If latest point of STB is trading below the mean (negative RV signal), it’s considered expensive (positive RV signal). Conversely, when above the mean it is considered cheap. Both Spread and Regression RV signals have different options of look-back window, meaning the signal is built based on 10 days, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 years of historical data. Back-testing The underpinning assumption of the RV signals is that all signals follow mean reversion. For back-testing, we want to see if the underpinning assumption holds in different regions. We want to evaluate if the spread is moving in the same direction or not as indicated by the RV signal. Let’s assume we choose look-back window of 3 months and expect the mean-reversion happens in 30 days (holding period = 30 days). As shown in the graph below. If the current CUSIP is trading at px adj OAS of 100 bps, while it’s issuer curve (after curve fitting) at the same tenor shows 90 bps of px adj OAS, it means that the CUSIP is currently trading cheap relative to its issuer curve. If the signal of this CUSIP has a RV z-score of 1, which means that this CUSIP is currently trading at 1 stdev above the 3 months historical STC mean. If we hold this CUSIP for 30 days (expect the mean-reversion happens in 30 days), if the RV signal is the right indication, we are expecting it to be mean reverted, which means that the STC should becomes smaller regardless of the CUSIP or the IC moves. At T + 30, both scenarios shown in the graph on the right-hand side follow mean reversion, where we are expecting this CUSIP to become rich. Likewise, the opposite scenario exhibits a divergent dynamic. To perform a thorough back-testing, we tested RV signals with all available look-back periods that the signals are based on, 10 days, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, and 2 years. We are expecting the signals to be mean reverted, but mean reversion can happen at different time frame. So we look at different holding periods to see how mean reversion occurs, at 2 weeks, 1 month, 2 months, 3 months, and 6 months, which can also be extended in the future as needed. In addition, to better understand the performance of RV signals, we performed bucket analysis on RV signals as well as maturities of the bonds. Bin the signals in buckets of (-Inf, -3.0], (-3.0, -2.5], (-2.5, -2.0], …, (2.5, 3.0], (3.0, Inf], and maturity (yrs) in buckets of 0-3, 3-5, 5-7, 7-10, 10-15, 15-20, 20-30, 30+. For the back-testing results discussed below, we are testing with 2 years of historical data from 2020-2022. And we breakdown the analysis by currency as well. The results above show the statistics of the residual (STC) movement of CUSIPs in the format of average, median, standard deviation, and P-value. To be more specific, on the far right, we can specify currency, RV signal look-back window, maturity bucket, and historical dates. In this case, we are looking at USD with look-back window of 90 days (3 months). To better understand what the result means, if we look at the upper left cell, where RV z-score bucket is in (3, Inf) with a holding period of 2 weeks, it means that for all bonds in the historical testing data with z-score of 3 and above, on average, residual (STC) tightened 5.79 bps over 2 weeks of holding period. It indicates mean reversion preserves for this specific z-score bucket with this holding period, as positive z-score indicates that the bonds are currently trading cheap (above the mean) and expected to become rich (expensive – smaller px adj oas) over time. From the result, we can see that the monotonical increasing in the residual movements (bps) with the decreasing in the z-score buckets, which indicate overall mean reversion occurs in this scenario. The stronger the signals are, the larger residual movements occurred. A small p-values give stronger support statistically. We also look at how hit rate performs over holding periods by buckets over time. The graph above shows the daily average hit rate of CUSIPs that exhibited residual change in right direction over the holding period. Similarly, we find that the stronger the signals are (more stdev away from the mean), the higher the hit rates are over time. Throughout the back-testing, we’ve found that RV signals strongly follow mean reversion in USD, with different look-back windows and holding periods. The longer the look-back window (2yr) as well as the holding period (6 months), the stronger the signals are. CAD also tends to follow mean reversion, but not as strong as USD. For European and Australian market (EUR, GBP, AUD), mean reversion is minimally from the observation. The main reason is that the bulk of EUR and GBP issuers have very few debts outstanding, and as a result, the curves fitted are less reliable compared with USD. The quant team is working on improving the curve fitting for the next step. Additional highlight on OAS Analysis Apart from back testing the RV signals, we did analysis on OAS in addition to the residual (STC). The reason behind it is that we want to have a better understanding of the market overall. We’ve noticed that the average daily OAS movement is monotonically increasing with the decreasing of RV z-score during 2020-2022. This indicates that rich bonds cheapen more than cheap bonds over time. The yields on rich bonds are increasing at a faster rate than the yields on cheap bonds. This OAS analysis gives us a better understanding of the impact of beta with given period. We have the back-testing results built into the Tableau report, and plan to have it refreshed quarterly to keep track of the behavior of RV signals. On top of that, the report also has a version to select by issuers based on need"

text: Reframe and rephrase in more polished language using literary jargon and in active voice. Avoid repeating words or Ideas "In her 1984 essay, “Under Western Eyes: Feminist Scholarship and Colonial Discourses,” postcolonial feminist scholar Chandra Talpade Mohanty put forth a scathing critique – not just of Western feminist scholarship, but also the ways in which it tends to oversimplify and stereotype the experiences of women in the Global South (Mohanty 337). Mohanty’s central point is that Western feminists should avoid constructing monolithic categories of “the third-world woman,” as such a characterization only perpetuates colonial discourses (Mohanty 342). She identifies six dominant feminist discourses that contribute to the portrayal of “Third World women” as a unified and homogenous group. These discourses depict “Third World women” as victims of male violence, colonial oppression, family systems, development processes, and religious ideologies. These representations often position “Third World women” as passive and vulnerable, lacking agency and independence."

text: Перепишите на русском языке предоставленный текст, сохраняя его общий смысл и структуру, но используя: Разнообразную лексику, Перефразирование и переформулирование предложений, Изменение порядка слов и структуры предложений, Улучшение читабельности и удобочитаемости, Сохранение точности и ясности исходного текста. Дополнительные указания: Избегайте использования плагиата или перефразирования с помощью синонимайзеров, Стремитесь к созданию уникального и оригинального текста, который не будет идентичен исходному, Ни одно предложение из созданного вами не должно точь-в-точь повторять исходное, уберите из текста весь мусор вроде ссылок. Разбей текст на абзацы. Заголовок для текста придумывать не нужно. Вот сам текст: Editors' notes This article has been reviewed according to Science X's editorial process and policies. Editors have highlighted the following attributes while ensuring the content's credibility: fact-checked trusted source proofread Using waste to purify water may sound counterintuitive. But at TU Wien, this is exactly what has now been achieved. Researchers have developed a special nanostructure to filter a widespread class of harmful dyes from water. A crucial component is a material that is considered waste: used cellulose, for example in the form of cleaning cloths or paper cups. The cellulose is utilized to coat a fine nano-fabric to create an efficient filter for polluted water. The paper is published in the journal Small Science. Organic dyes represent the largest group of synthetic dyes, including so-called azo compounds. They are widely used in the textile industry, even in countries where little attention is paid to environmental protection, and the dyes often end up in unfiltered wastewater. "This is dangerous because such dyes degrade very slowly, they can remain in the water for a long time and pose great danger to humans and nature," says Prof. Günther Rupprechter from the Institute of Materials Chemistry at TU Wien. There are various materials that can bind such dyes. But that alone is not enough. "If you simply let the polluted water flow over a filter film that can bind dyes, the cleaning effect is low," explains Rupprechter. "It's much better to create a nanofabric out of lots of tiny fibers and let the water seep through." The water then comes into contact with a much larger surface area, and thus many more organic dye molecules can be bound. "We are working with semi-crystalline nanocellulose, which can be produced from waste material," says Qaisar Maqbool, first author of the study and postdoc in Rupprechter's research group. "Metal-containing substances are often used for similar purposes. Our material, on the other hand, is completely harmless to the environment, and we can also produce it by upcycling waste paper." This nano-cellulose is "spun" together with the plastic polyacrylonitrile into nanostructures. However, this requires a lot of technical skill. The team from the TU Wien was successful with a so-called electrospinning process. In this process, the material is sprayed in liquid form, the droplets are electrically charged and sent through an electric field. "This ensures that the liquid forms extremely fine threads with a diameter of 180 to 200 nanometers during curing," says Rupprechter. These threads form a fine tissue with a high surface area—a so-called "nanoweb." A network of threads can be placed on one square centimeter, with a total surface area of more than 10 cm2. The tests with these cellulose-coated nanostructures were very successful: In three cycles, water contaminated with violet dye was purified, and 95% of the dye was removed. "The dyes remain stored in the nanoweb. You can then either dispose of the entire web or regenerate it, dissolve the stored dyes and reuse the filter fabric," explains Rupprechter. However, more work needs to be done: evaluating the mechanical properties of the sophisticated nanowebs, conducting biocompatibility tests, assessing sensitivity to more complex pollutants, and achieving scalability to industrial-grade standards. Now Rupprechter and his research team want to investigate how this dye filter technology can be transferred to other areas of application. "This technology could also be very interesting for the medical field," Rupprechter believes. "Dialysis, for example, also needs filtering out very specific chemical substances from a liquid." Coated nanofabrics may be useful for such applications. More information: Qaisar Maqbool et al, Waste‐Valorized Nanowebs for Crystal Violet Removal from Water, Small Science (2024). DOI: 10.1002/smsc.202300286 Provided by Vienna University of Technology

Вот сам текст: Editors' notes This article has been reviewed according to <redacted> Science X (ORG) </redacted>'s editorial process and policies. Editors have highlighted the following attributes while ensuring the content's credibility: fact-checked trusted source proofread Using waste to purify water may sound counterintuitive. But at <redacted> TU Wien (ORG) </redacted>, this is exactly what has now been achieved. Researchers have developed a special nanostructure to filter a widespread class of harmful dyes from water. A crucial component is a material that is considered waste: used cellulose, for example in the form of cleaning cloths or paper cups. The cellulose is utilized to coat a fine nano-fabric to create an efficient filter for polluted water. The paper is published in the journal Small Science. Organic dyes represent the largest group of synthetic dyes, including so-called azo compounds. They are widely used in the textile industry, even in countries where little attention is paid to environmental protection, and the dyes often end up in unfiltered wastewater. "This is dangerous because such dyes degrade very slowly, they can remain in the water for a long time and pose great danger to humans and nature," says <redacted> Prof. Günther Rupprechter (PERSON) </redacted> from <redacted> the Institute of Materials Chemistry at TU Wien (ORG) </redacted>. There are various materials that can bind such dyes. But that alone is not enough. "If you simply let the polluted water flow over a filter film that can bind dyes, the cleaning effect is low," explains <redacted> Rupprechter (PERSON) </redacted>. "It's much better to create a nanofabric out of lots of tiny fibers and let the water seep through." The water then comes into contact with a much larger surface area, and thus many more organic dye molecules can be bound. "We are working with semi-crystalline nanocellulose, which can be produced from waste material," says <redacted> Qaisar Maqbool (PERSON) </redacted>, first author of the study and postdoc in <redacted> Rupprechter (ORG) </redacted>'s research group. "Metal-containing substances are often used for similar purposes. Our material, on the other hand, is completely harmless to the environment, and we can also produce it by upcycling waste paper." This nano-cellulose is "spun" together with the plastic polyacrylonitrile into nanostructures. However, this requires a lot of technical skill. The team from <redacted> the TU Wien (ORG) </redacted> was successful with a so-called electrospinning process. In this process, the material is sprayed in liquid form, the droplets are electrically charged and sent through an electric field. "This ensures that the liquid forms extremely fine threads with a diameter of 180 to 200 nanometers during curing," says <redacted> Rupprechter (PERSON) </redacted>. These threads form a fine tissue with a high surface area—a so-called "nanoweb." A network of threads can be placed on one square centimeter, with a total surface area of more than 10 cm2. The tests with these cellulose-coated nanostructures were very successful: In three cycles, water contaminated with violet dye was purified, and 95% of the dye was removed. "The dyes remain stored in the nanoweb. You can then either dispose of the entire web or regenerate it, dissolve the stored dyes and reuse the filter fabric," explains <redacted> Rupprechter (PERSON) </redacted>. However, more work needs to be done: evaluating the mechanical properties of the sophisticated nanowebs, conducting biocompatibility tests, assessing sensitivity to more complex pollutants, and achieving scalability to industrial-grade standards. Now <redacted> Rupprechter (PERSON) </redacted> and his research team want to investigate how this dye filter technology can be transferred to other areas of application. "This technology could also be very interesting for the medical field," <redacted> Rupprechter (PERSON) </redacted> believes. "Dialysis, for example, also needs filtering out very specific chemical substances from a liquid." Coated nanofabrics may be useful for such applications. More information: <redacted> Qaisar Maqbool (PERSON) </redacted> et al, Waste‐Valorized Nanowebs for Crystal Violet Removal from Water, Small Science (2024). text: break this into paragraphs:The Politics of International Trade, as I want to explore the politics behind international trade and understand how global economic policies, trade agreements, and political interactions influence international commerce and the global marketplace. This course will provide me with the necessary knowledge and perspective in this area. Studying global governance is also important to me, and the course IR 309: Global Governance examines the functioning and cooperation of international organizations like the United Nations to tackle global issues. I want to understand how these institutions manage global affairs and address challenges. Another course that interests me is IR 308: Globalization, which covers various aspects of globalization, including its impacts on politics, economics, culture, environment, and social relations. I have a particular interest in critically analyzing the benefits and drawbacks of globalization. Furthermore, Professor Aronson’s specialization in international political economy, strategic alliances, and international telecommunications is an additional reason why I want to study International Relations at USC. With his expertise, I hope to gain insights into how alliances between countries are formed, their influence on decision-making, and their implications on the global stage. Additionally, the research group “Near Crisis Project” at USC intrigues me as it focuses on escalation processes. Being a part of this research would allow me to learn about the prediction mechanism of escalation where I want to apply it to project to development of China-Taiwan friction.. Moreover, USC offers a wide range of extracurricular activities that I am excited to engage in. Attending Late Night 'SC and the involvement fair will provide an opportunity to get to know the student body. Joining the USC volunteer center, specifically initiatives like Serve LA 2022, will allow me to actively contribute to helping others. Additionally, joining the USC student government will provide valuable experience in a governmental institution and allow me to apply my skills in a practical setting. Finally, I am interested in participating in the Glass Paint night, as it seems like a fun and creative activity to try out. Overall, USC offers a diverse range of courses, research opportunities, and extracurricular activities that align with my interests and passion for International Relations.

text: 2.1 Human AAA tissue samples RNA sequence Five human AAA tissues and their adjacent normal aortic tissue were collected for sequencing. Human AAA samples were obtained with the approval of the Ethics Committee of the Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University. The diagnosis of AAA was confirmed by computed tomography angiography prior to surgery in all patients. Adjacent normal aortic tissue and AAA samples were obtained from 5 patients with elevated IgE who underwent open surgery. All tissue samples were frozen in liquid nitrogen immediately after resection and stored at −80°C until further processing. Detailed information of patients was shown in Table 1. Quality control, sequencing and further analysis of AAA tissue samples were carried out.

All tissue samples were frozen in liquid nitrogen immediately after resection and stored at −80°C until further processing. Detailed information of patients was shown in Table 1. Quality control, sequencing and further analysis of AAA tissue samples were carried out.

text: Story prompt: 13-year-old Max was headed to a friend’s house. As someone who can’t drive yet, he uses a ride-sharing app to get from one place to another. On this day, however, he ended up sharing a ride with a stranger. 13 years old as well, she was dressed fashionably and had an air of popularity to her. Someone who definitely went out with friends more often than others. According to the app, her destination was a large shopping mall, closer than Max’s friend’s house, thought pretty far away. It would take about 30 minutes to get to the mall. In the meantime, Max, who was never one to initiate conversation, kept to himself. Still, 30 minutes was gonna take a while. “So… mall, huh?”, awkwardly asked Max to start a conversation. “Yeah.”, was the response she gave him. Doesn’t seem like she was interested. Why would she? Everyone’s a stranger in the car. This was gonna be a long ride. Still, it didn’t seem like she was completely cold and distant. After a few minutes had passed, Max opened up with, “Hanging out with a friend today. Thinking you’re doing the same?” The girl responded, “Yeah. Probably just gonna go window shopping.”, while on her phone. “Got any other plans after that?”, asked Max. Even she was surprised to answer him so casually, saying, “We got basketball practice today at 4.” Max replied, “Oh, cool. I had a feeling you were the sporty type too.” It didn’t take long for the seemingly awkward boy and the seemingly disinterested girl to actually engage in long conversations. It didn’t even register to them that they were already at the mall. “I’m Max, by the way.” The girl replied, “My name’s Suzanna. Or Suzie, but whatever. It was nice talkin’ to you, Max.”, just before closing the door and going inside the mall. As the car began to head to his friend’s house, Max couldn’t help but think to himself, “I just had a good conversation with a stranger. Pretty, too.”

text: TEST LOG 085-3: Date: [REDACTED] Lead Researcher: Dr. [REDACTED] Subject: SCP-085 (referred to as “Cassy”) [Test Scenario] Objective: To further explore the capabilities of SCP-978 (Desire Camera) in capturing Cassy’s 2D form and to observe her interaction with the resulting photograph. Test Setup: Cassy will be placed on an 8 x 10 inch sheet of paper, the same size as her usual confinement. SCP-978 will be operated by Researcher [REDACTED] to capture Cassy’s photograph. Procedure: 1. Cassy is positioned on the sheet of paper, ensuring proper contact. 2. Researcher [REDACTED] prepares SCP-978 for use, offering clear instruction to Cassy about the upcoming photograph. 3. SCP-978 is activated, and a photograph of Cassy is taken. 4. The resulting photograph is immediately retrieved for examination. [Test Results and Analysis] Photograph Description: The photograph captured by SCP-978 appears to be an accurate representation of Cassy’s 2D form as seen visually. No alterations or additional information were observed. Cassy is depicted on an 8 x 10 inch sheet of paper, occupying the same position and proportions as her physical form. The details of her appearance remain consistent, including her dark hair, blue eyes, and delicate facial features. Cassy’s Interaction with the Photograph: Upon viewing the photograph, Cassy exhibits signs of curiosity and excitement. She moves closer to the photograph, studying it intently, and begins to interact with it by touching her own image on the photograph’s surface. As she touches the photograph, her expression turns to one of surprise, suggesting a tangible connection between her physical self and the representation captured by SCP-978. Researcher [REDACTED]: Cassy, what are your thoughts and feelings when you interact with the photograph of yourself? Cassy: [Writes] Connection. Familiar. Researcher [REDACTED]: It is fascinating to see your reaction, Cassy. The photograph seems to have established a sense of connection and familiarity for you. Now, do you have any questions or concerns regarding the photograph or the test? Cassy: [Writes] No questions. New test? Researcher [REDACTED]: Understood, Cassy. We will consider new test scenarios for the future. Your feedback is valuable in expanding our understanding of your abilities. We will continue to prioritize your well-being and safety while providing stimulating experiences. Cassy, based on your experience with SCP-978 and the photograph, would you like to participate in more tests involving SCP-978 in the future? Cassy: [Writes] Yes. More connection. Researcher [REDACTED]: We will certainly take that into consideration, Cassy. It is important for us to facilitate more opportunities for you to establish a sense of connection and exploration. We will work towards creating new test scenarios to fulfill that objective. [CONCLUSION] Researcher [REDACTED]: Thank you for your cooperation, Cassy. Your feedback and participation in these tests are crucial for our ongoing research. If you have any further thoughts or concerns, please don’t hesitate to communicate them to us. Take care, and we look forward to future interactions. Cassy: [Smiles and nods] [END OF TEST LOG]

text: Summarize this paragraph:The ecological diversity of the KSA allows multiple opportunities for the evolution of variation in both mosquitoes and their pathogens. Large-scale movements of people, including the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, large-scale use of foreign workers and new developmental projects engender environmental heterogeneity and complex epidemiology. The wide variation in ecological settings may complicate the understanding of spatial/temporal characteristics and population dynamics of mosquito vectors of pathogens that cause diseases in humans. Investigators may be reluctant to conduct ecological studies in the KSA because field work is labour-intensive and time-consuming. Moreover, due to habitat heterogeneity, which in the KSA is often extreme, there are species of only seven mosquito genera in the country. Here we present the first complete list (see above) of the mosquito species that definitely are known to occur in the KSA. In some cases, ecological and morphological studies have shown that some species are members of species complexes. There are members of four Anopheles species complexes in the country, including the An. gambiae, An. fluviatilis, An. culicifacies and An. subpictus complexes. The Afrotropical An. gambiae complex consists of eight species, which includes malaria vectors (An. gambiae, An. arabiensis, An. bwambae, An. coluzzii, An. merus and An. melas) and non-vectors (An. quadriannulatus and An. amharicus) [70, 71]. Anopheles arabiensis is the only member of the complex with a range that extends outside of Africa into the southwestern and western areas of the Arabian Peninsula, occurring in the KSA and Yemen, where it is the major malaria vector [2, 3, 7, 72,73,74,75]. Most ecological studies conducted in the KSA recorded the presence of An. arabiensis (often as An. gambiae) in different life stages [27, 29, 30, 51]. Moreover, molecular analysis based on the internal transcribed spacer (ITS2) region of rDNA has shown that An. arabiensis (GenBank: KM068071) is the only member of An. gambiae complex present in the KSA [59]. The An. fluviatilis complex is a group of mosquitoes that is widely distributed in southern and southwestern Asia and includes important malaria vectors [76]. The complex includes four species informally denoted as species S, T, U and V [77,78,79,80,81]. Anopheles fluviatilis S is mainly anthropophilic, endophilic and a very competent malaria vector [52]. Species T and U are primarily zoophilic, exophagic and exophilic, and are regarded as poor- or non-vectors of malaria even though they are responsible for malaria transmission in mountainous and hilly areas in Asia, including Iran [80, 82]. Anopheles fluviatilis (s.l.) was recorded in the eastern and western regions of the KSA by Mattingly & Knight [2], Wills et al. [31] and Al-Ghamdi et al. [51]. It is not known whether species T or U or both are present in the KSA. The An. culicifacies complex consists of five sibling species, informally named species A, B, C, D and E, based on cytotaxonomic and molecular evidence [53, 76, 83]. These species have distinct geographical distributions, blood-feeding behaviour and vectorial capacity for malaria transmission [54, 84, 85]. The complex is widely distributed from southern China to Iran, the Arabian Peninsula and Ethiopia [86]. Species E is the most important malaria vector in the Indian subcontinent, and is highly anthropophilic and endophilic [87]. The other sibling species have low anthropophilic index or are highly zoophilic, and are considered poor- or non-malaria vectors in India and Sri Lanka [52, 88]. Available data indicate there are at least two species of the complex in Iran [89], but only the presence of species A has been confirmed based on cytogenetic and molecular evidence; the second species may be a new member of the complex [90]. Further study is needed to determine which member or members of the complex are present in the KSA. The An. subpictus complex consists of four species in India, informally denoted as species A, B, C and D, based on morphological, chromosomal and molecular differences [91, 92]. As is the case in Iran [90], it is not known which species of the complex is present in the KSA. Anopheles stephensi is the main malaria vector in the eastern region of the KSA, but members of the An. fluviatilis and An. culicifacies complexes, which are important malaria vectors in other parts of Asia [2, 3, 55, 74], may contribute to malaria transmission. In Asia, An. stephensi, An. culicifacies (s.l.) and An. fluviatilis (s.l.) consist of different ecoforms that are restricted to rural or urban areas with different degrees of involvement in malaria transmission [54, 76, 85]. Anopheles stephensi is a major vector in Asia and the Middle East, including, in addition to the eastern KSA, areas of Iran, Pakistan, Afghanistan, India and southern China [87]. It includes three ecological variants (egg phenotypes): the mysorensis, typical and intermediate forms, which are based and distinguished on egg morphology [87, 93,94,95,96]. The typical (type) form is mainly found in urban areas, whereas the intermediate and mysorensis forms are mainly found in rural environments [87]. The blood-feeding behaviour and role of these forms in malaria transmission varies in different geographical regions. In Iran, the type form is highly anthropophilic and a major malaria vector, whereas the mysorensis form is mainly zoophilic and a poor- or non-vector [97]. In contrast, the mysorensis form is an important malaria vector in India [98]. These differences might be due to the type of host available and the presence of certain mosquito genotypes with different host preference and susceptibility to malarial parasites. Molecular study using two different markers (ITS2 and cox1) did not reveal any differences between An. stephensi (ITS2, GenBank: KM052589; and cox1, GenBank: KJ528887–KJ528894) in two distant cities of the KSA (Al-Ahsaa and Dammam) where different phenotypes might be present [59]. Anopheles azaniae was first encountered in Saudi Arabia during the collection of mosquitoes for Rift Valley virus isolation in the Jizan Region [17], and subsequently collected in the same region by Alahmed et al. [18] and Khater et al. [7]. The record of this species in the Riyadh Region [32], which is a very large eastern region that shares its southern border with Yemen, requires confirmation. The record of this species in the more northerly western Al-Madinah Al-Munawarah Region [33] is doubtful and a probable misidentification of either An. dthali or An. rhodesiensis rupicolus. Anopheles azaniae was previously known to occur in neighbouring Yemen [14], where two morphological forms were recently discovered, the typical form and a previously unrecognized form not immediately identifiable as An. azaniae [99]. A single specimen of the atypical form had a mixed human/bovine blood meal, indicating that females are anthropophilic and should be considered a potential vector of malarial protozoa. It seems possible that further studies in the southwest of the KSA may detect the presence of the atypical form. A species of the genus Coquillettidia collected in the Eastern Province of the KSA was identified as a species of Mansonia in the study of Wills et al. [31]. According to the online catalogue of the Walter Reed Biosystematics Unit [24], only two species of the tribe Mansoniini are known to occur in more or less arid countries of the Middle East, Cq. (Coquillettidia) buxtoni in Israel and Syria and Cq. (Coq.) richiardii in Iran, Syria and Turkey. With that in mind, it seems likely that the generic identification of Wills et al. [31] was based on keys available at the time, e.g. Mattingly [100], which treated Coquillettidia as a subgenus of Mansonia. In view of the proximity of eastern areas of the KSA to Iran, we are confident that the mosquitoes identified as a species of Mansonia by Wills et al. [31] were most likely specimens of Cq. richiardii. Many of the occurrence records for Cx. pipiens and Cx. quinquefasciatus in the KSA are problematic. Culex pipiens generally occurs north of a line transecting the KSA between Jeddah in the west and Al-Hasa in the east. Culex quinquefasciatus occurs in the more southerly region of the Arabian Peninsula, with isolated populations of Cx. pipiens occurring in the southwestern mountains [5]. Introgression occurs between the two species where their distributions overlap in central KSA (see figure 3 in Harbach [101]). Both species exhibit considerable variation in the larval and adult stages, and they cannot always be distinguished with certainty. They are only reliably distinguished by characters of the male genitalia; however, their separation is complicated by the occurrence of hybrid forms in the central transitional zone and eastern coastal region of the country. Hybrids are morphologically more variable than the parental species, and are only reliably distinguished from the parental species by the DV/D ratio calculated from measurements based on the form and relationships of the dorsal and ventral arms of the male genitalia [102, 103]. It is not possible to distinguish hybrid larvae and females from the parental species. For this reason, some hybrid specimens collected in and around the zone of introgression have undoubtedly been misidentified as either Cx. pipiens or Cx. quinquefasciatus. Larvae and adults collected north of the hybrid zone that have been identified as Cx. quinquefasciatus are misidentified specimens of Cx. pipiens, and those collected south of the zone that have been identified as Cx. pipiens, with the possible exception of those collected in the southwestern mountains, are misidentified specimens of Cx. quinquefasciatus. Future studies based on dissections of male genitalia or DNA sequence analysis of larvae and adults are needed to substantiate species identifications and collection records. Culex quinquefasciatus is an important vector of the microfilariae that cause lymphatic filariasis. Culex torrentium is listed as a species of the KSA in the online catalogue of the Walter Reed Biosystematics Unit [24] based on a number of reports, including Alahmed et al. [18, 19], Al Ahmed et al. [20, 28], Kheir et al. [34], Alahmed [35] and Hassan et al. [41]. However, it is obvious that the identification of Cx. torrentium in the KSA by these authors is based on unreliable characters of larvae and adult habitus principally using the keys of Harbach [4, 5]. This species can only be distinguished from members of the Cx. pipiens complex with certainty based on features of the male genitalia. Additionally, Cx. torrentium is a Palaearctic species whose distribution only extends south into Turkey and possibly into northern Iran [90, 104, 105]. As noted by Harbach [5], early records of Cx. torrentium in Iraq are doubtful, and the species is not now listed as present in that country [106, 107]. For these reasons, Cx. torrentium is excluded from the list of mosquito species known to occur in the KSA. Four species of the subgenus Culex of the genus Culex occur in the southwestern Afrotropical Region of the Arabian Peninsula, i.e. Cx. decens, Cx. duttoni, Cx. simpsoni and Cx. univittatus. These species were only known to occur in Yemen [5, 108] until they were more recently found in the Asir Region [63], Jizan (Jazan) Region [18] and Najran Province [28], which border Yemen in the southwest corner of the KSA. The records of two of these species, Cx. simpsoni and Cx. univittatus, require confirmation because their identification was based on larvae and adults. They are only reliably distinguished from Cx. sinaiticus and Cx. perexiguus, respectively, based on the morphology of the male genitalia. Records of the two species in more northerly areas of the country are more doubtful. Since Culex salisburiensis has been known to be present in Yemen since 1953 [108], there is no reason to doubt its occurrence in the adjacent Afrotropical area of the KSA [21, 67]. On the contrary, the reported finding of Cx. wigglesworthi in the Asir Region by Al Ashry et al. [67] is certainly a misidentification. The authors collected 4307 Culex larvae, two of which were identified as Cx. nebulosus, three as Cx. perexiguus and two as Cx. wigglesworthi. Larvae were identified using the keys of Hopkins [109], Mattingly & Knight [2] and Harbach [4, 5]. The identification of Cx. nebulosus and Cx. perexiguus may be correct as these two species are included in the keys of Mattingly & Knight (Cx. nebulosus) and Harbach (Cx. nebulosus and Cx. perexiguus). Use of the badly outdated keys of Hopkins [109] for African species published in 1952, leading to the identification of Cx. wigglesworthi, is problematic, nonetheless because it is a sub-Sharan species with closest records in southern Sudan, South Sudan and Kenya. Consequently, as it seems likely that the two larvae were misidentified specimens of either Cx. perexiguus or Cx. univittatus, Cx. wigglesworthi is excluded from the list of mosquito species known to occur in the KSA. Alahmed [35], Alahmed et al. [36] and Khater et al. [7] recorded the presence of Uranotaenia (Pseudoficalbia) unguiculata in eastern and southwestern areas of the KSA. The authors, however, were apparently unaware of the earlier description of Ur. unguiculata pefflyi by Stone [69], and the recognized presence of only that form in eastern parts of the KSA [31]. Consequently, as it is unlikely that the typical form, Ur. unguiculata unguiculata, is present in the country, only the subspecies described and named by Stone [69] is included in the list.

text: simplify this: However, evaluating managers based on the data above could be misleading. When analyzing hedge managers, we can consider other factors, such as past performance and investment strategy. Based on the 7-year net annual return shown in Exhibit 8, Omega and Tiger have higher NAV returns among market-sensitive hedge funds. Among the defensive hedge funds, Zweig outperformed. It is important that Omega's data is missing data and can lead to bias of the higher numbers. Overall, combining information ratio, alpha, and past performance, Tiger and Zweig are hedge funds that can be trusted.
