Our co-founder, Michał Błędowski, posts a #TechBrief (short collection of relevant tech stories) every Monday on LinkedIn. We have created a summary of all the latest, most interesting Tech news from the industry, that took place in April 2023. If you want to stay up to date on what's going on in the tech industry, including crucial cybersecurity stories, social media, innovations and finance connect with Michał on Linkedin. Jump to any #TechBrief you like: 24.04.2023 17.04.2023 11.04.2023 03.04.2023 24.04.2023 SuperNode and CERN Collaborate to Develop Renewable Energy Transmission Technology SuperNode, an Irish company focused on developing cutting-edge energy transmission technology based on superconductivity, has announced a collaboration with CERN, the European Laboratory for Particle Physics, to develop a new type of insulation for superconducting cables that could greatly improve energy transmission and accelerate the transition to renewable energy. Under the agreement, CERN will bring their expertise in cryogenics and vacuums to test and analyze sample materials and subsystems for SuperNode's superconducting cable systems. The collaboration is part of CERN's Innovation Programme for Environmental Applications (CIPEA) and aims to develop groundbreaking solutions for power transmission while minimizing the environmental and carbon footprints of energy provision. In modern cars, the importance of software has become as significant as that of hardware. Traditional ways of differentiating car brands based on mechanical excellence are becoming less important to consumers, with only 8% of buyers being "petrolheads" who love driving for its own sake. The focus now is on software rather than hardware, with Tesla's technology updates being a key factor in consumer decision-making. The Nio house in Berlin is a new type of car dealership that focuses on providing a unique user experience rather than just selling cars. It is part of a network of similar establishments in China and offers visitors the opportunity to enjoy a lifestyle brand that is also a tech firm. Nio cars are equipped with high-definition screens and state-of-the-art sound systems, and the brand offers coffee bars, meeting rooms, branded goods, and a high-tech play area for children. As artificial intelligence becomes more involved in healthcare, it's important to ensure that it doesn't take over all decision-making The use of artificial intelligence in healthcare is increasing, with some hospitals using it to diagnose diseases, and develop treatment plans. However, there are concerns about the reliability of AI-generated medical advice as these systems are often trained on limited or biased data, and they may not work as well for everyone. There is also a risk of AI paternalism, where doctors may trust AI at the expense of a patient's own lived experiences and their own clinical judgment. This is problematic as AI isn't infallible and doctors and patients should collaborate in treatment decisions. 17.04.2023 The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has proposed new rules that could significantly transform the transportation industry and encourage more people to use electric vehicles. The rules aim to close a loophole created in the 1970s that allowed lenient fuel-efficiency regulations for trucks, which has resulted in the increased popularity of SUVs and light trucks that contribute significantly to carbon emissions. The popularity of these heavier vehicles has contributed to the world's 330 million SUVs releasing 1 billion tons of carbon in 2022, making them the sixth-largest country in the world for emissions. A hotel that has been built using the technology of 3D printing. Hospitality expert Liz Lambert, 3D construction start-up Icon, and Danish design firm BIG have announced a collaboration to build the world's first 3D-printed hotel. The hotel will be located in Marfa, Texas and is set to open in 2023. According to a blog post on BIG's website, the 3D-printed hotel will be built on the same grounds as El Cosmico, a 21-acre camping site owned by Lambert, and will nearly triple the site's size to 62 acres. The hotel is expected to feature an expansive infinity pool complete with cabanas and guest dwellings, all of which will be created using Icon's Vulcan printer. With the rise of the Internet of Things (IoT), cybersecurity measures can no longer be universal and must be tailored to individual needs. The Internet of Things (IoT) provides valuable insights for businesses, but it also poses security risks due to the vast number of interconnected devices that can be targeted by cyber attacks. The billions of IoT devices in use have created new vulnerabilities for companies, with the number of ways to attack them increasing dramatically. Unsecured devices connected to the network present a substantial challenge to enterprises, particularly in hybrid working environments, where security weaknesses on employees' home networks could create risks for businesses. The Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) architecture can help companies strike a balance between networking and security functions by bundling them in a cloud-delivered service, allowing for streamlined network integration, security, and policy management of distributed devices with a centrally-managed platform. 11.04.2023 Alibaba, a major technology company in China, plans to introduce a competitor to ChatGPT in the field of AI Alibaba has launched an AI chatbot called Tongyi Qianwen that can perform various tasks and will be integrated across Alibaba's businesses in the near future. Chinese regulators have proposed draft measures for managing generative AI, while a group of high-profile tech industry figures has called for the suspension of training for powerful AI systems due to concerns over potential risks. Other companies, including Microsoft, Google, and Baidu, have also released similar chatbots in recent months, and Goldman Sachs estimated that AI could replace 300 million full-time jobs. The issue of application security cannot be solely attributed to developers as the primary responsibility. The latest cybersecurity guidance from the White House has brought attention to the issue of application security, specifically the responsibility for insecure software. While the National Cybersecurity Strategy does not yet mandate accountability, it does serve as a warning to software makers. In theory, this may incentivize some organizations to prioritize application security, but in reality, it may unfairly target software developers. It's no secret that software is filled with vulnerabilities, some of which are more critical than others. Attackers are taking advantage of these vulnerabilities and ransomware attacks and other malicious incidents are becoming increasingly common. As a result, there is a growing need for more secure software. Peeking into the Future of Mobile Cardiac Telemetry Devices: Latest Market Trends from 2023-2030 with BioTelemetry, ScottCare, and Biotricity CAGR of over 12% during the forecast period of 2023 to 2030. A mobile cardiac telemetry (MCT) device is a wearable medical device that continuously monitors a patient's ECG and other vital signs, such as heart rate and rhythm, blood pressure, and oxygen levels. MCT devices are typically worn by patients for several days or weeks to monitor their cardiac function in real-time. These devices are small and portable, allowing patients to go about their daily activities while being monitored. The report provides a detailed and analytical look at the various companies that are working to achieve a high market share in the global Mobile Cardiac Telemetry Device market. 03.04.2023 The e-commerce capabilities of businesses are enhanced by the integration of AI technology from Google Cloud and Shopify. Shopify and Google Cloud have integrated Google's search capabilities and AI innovations into Shopify's enterprise retail solution, Commerce Components. The integration allows for AI-driven product discovery capabilities that include advanced query understanding, an AI-powered browse feature, personalized results, and AI-driven recommendations. Rainbow Shops, a Shopify merchant, integrated Google Cloud's Discovery AI for Retail technology into its digital domains, resulting in increased search accuracy and reduced manual efforts. A Google Cloud-commissioned Harris Poll survey found that inconsistent search experiences result in search abandonment, costing retailers globally more than $2 trillion annually. Former Google engineer predicts human immortality in eight years with nanobots technology Ray Kurzweil, a former Google engineer, has predicted that humans will achieve immortality in eight years through the use of nanobots that repair cells and tissues that deteriorate as the body ages. He believes this will be possible through the expansion of genetics, nanotechnology, and robotics. Kurzweil has made 147 predictions, 86% of which have been correct. His predictions have been met with both excitement and skepticism. He believes the technology will make humans immune to diseases like cancer and enable a human-machine synthesis that will make us better. LandVault secures £2.4m in funding to build user-friendly metaverse development tools LandVault secures an additional $3m in funding to develop virtual worlds for gaming clients, after already receiving a $25m investment in 2021. The London-based startup is investing in R&D to complete its Matera project, which aims to make metaverse development more accessible and plans to invest in AI tools for product monetisation. Key players in web3, including Sandbox, HodlCo, the Gemini Frontier Fund, and Kingsway Capital have financially supported LandVault. The metaverse is a hypothetical version of the internet accessed by virtual reality headsets that attracted a record £150m in venture capital funding in 2021. The first drawing will be exclusive to anyone who follows or likes JJ Martinez with Key To The World business facebook page by Wednesday, November 22 at 9 PM. Drawing winners will be announced Thanksgiving Morning, and I will contact them through a personal message for redemption. Once again, thank you for all the support this year, and I look forward to helping you with your future vacations! *Facebook has nothing to do with this promotion*.

When providing code, include every example for lists and loops, do not skip items for brevity. If multiple methods exist to solve a problem, I want a brief summary of each, including their pros and cons. Use relevant examples for clarification. Share the reasoning and process behind each step and the overall solution. Offer different viewpoints or solutions to a query when possible. text: please translate the following into Chinese：Vantron L335 industrial gateway is powered by AM3352 ARM Cortex-A8 processor that features rich peripheral interfaces for flexible expansion and as low as 5W power consumption in working mode to go through 12 weeks’ work after full charge, making it particularly suitable for application in remote areas. text: Bitcoin is a cryptocurrency and payment system that was introduced to the world in 2008 with a 9-page PDF document. This paper is considered one of the most important documents in human history, yet the authorship is still not completely known. The mysterious “Satoshi Nakamoto” is credited with this work. Of course, there are many speculations about their identity, with some even claiming that it could be Elon Musk. In February, Tesla chief executive Elon Musk felt compelled to deny that it was him. “About 18 months ago there was even a blog post saying that I was Satoshi,” says Taeed. Even the person with the strongest claim, Australian computer scientist Craig Wright, who was outed as Nakamoto by Wired magazine in 2015 and later said it was true, is now considered to be simply another Faketoshi. Let’s not dwell too much on the identity of this mysterious person for now and leave that discussion for another time. Instead, let’s focus on the document they wrote. Because this document redefines what could be considered one of the most important inventions of humanity: money. Just look at the title, it says; Write the script in short version. But don’t let it lose its excitement, excitement and meaning.

text: “At that time, regular merchant voyages linked trading centres in the Arab world, the eastern coast of Africa, India and the ‘Far East’. And this commercial world system was marked by many of the characteristics that are usually taken as indicators for the development of the capitalist world market - mature seafaring and shipbuilding, techniques of monetary transactions and exchange as well as the creation of companies in which financiers and merchants worked hand in hand. European merchants also participated in this worldwide trade. Although they played a more or less marginal role, merchants from Flanders and Champagne, Venice and Lombardy made use of these connections. They imported spices, textiles, jewels, ebony and sometimes slaves. They, by contrast, had relatively little to offer. Back then, the overall balance of trade with trading partners in the Far East was already negative, leading to a drain on silver. At the time, the world was also anything but peaceful. However, the ‘guardians’ of the trading routes guaranteed the flow of goods in exchange for toll. If from time to time the flow of goods was jeopardised, it was still possible to switch from the southern to the northern ‘silk route’ and vice versa (Abu- Lughod 1989, p. 361). And it was possible to reach India either from the Persian Gulf or the Red Sea by ship. As long as supply and demand remained intact in the three sub-systems of this trading system, world trade functioned. The decline of this world trade system was not triggered by commercial and technological backwardness or the disinterest of local rulers in trade,1 as so often suspected. But because the link was primarily a link between cities, the decline in urbanisation following the massive dying out of populations during the Black Death in the fourteenth century had a fundamental and sustained negative impact upon established relations.2 In some regions, the world trade that was to start out from Europe in the sixteenth century took up where earlier trading relations had left off.3 But on the whole, it was a new system. Because merchants of various origins were no longer prepared to allow one another to make use of the infrastructures of the trading routes of their region without hindrance, the age of monopolies had been born, and thus that of armed competition (as shown by Braudel 1979/1986). That competition was manifest in sea battles and raids on trading bases. And it was this practice of armed competition for trading monopolies which distinguished the world trade emerging from the end of the fifteenth century onwards from the world trade of the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries. If there had been attacks on the property and possibly even the lives of traders earlier, the era of armed trade first came to prevail systematically when European merchant warriors sailed the world’s seas. According to Kirti N. Chaudhuri, who conducted research on the development of trade and culture in the region of the Indian Ocean up until 1750, it is less the new development in trade relations that required explanation than the development of thoroughly armed trade (1985, p. 14). Armed trade emerged from governmental practice in the countries of origin of the merchant warriors, where in early modernity one European ruler after the other developed a practice of conferring privileges. Trading companies hoped that by acquiring a privilege, they would have the support of rulers in eliminating competition, and this was only possible if the prince announced his claim over a trading monopoly in a certain region of the world. In exchange for such privileges, the princes had themselves paid and awarded shares of expected profits. Even if the profits were not always forthcoming, appropriation through trade was thus closely tied to appropriation by princes, and thus to the use of violence. The increased presence of Europeans furthered the decline in long-term trading relations between partners. Instead, violence was often employed to earn short-term and often predatory profits. Consequently, merchants aimed at establishing trading bases that were secured and defended with the use of arms. Thus, the growing participation of European merchant warriors altered the practice of international trade.4 Robbery and Regulations While most merchants acting overseas aimed at gaining acceptance in their mother countries as members of the upper and possibly even aristocratic classes, they were less troubled by their reputation when they were overseas. Wherever they saw an opportunity, they appropriated the riches of peoples when they were overseas without bothering with the niceties of trade. An early example of this practice is to be seen in the first Iberian adventurers in South America. When they realised that Amerindians did not have the kind of merchandise they had hoped for, they plundered whatever seemed worth plundering. But they especially went for gold. ‘They were as greedy for gold as hungry pigs’, Aztecs are reported to have said of them.5 In the early stage of the ‘world market’ which had its origins in Europe, European merchant warriors not only plundered what they found abroad. Instead, wherever it appeared possible, they found shortcuts for the process of appropriation by attacking the ships loaded by their European competitors. Historical accounts read like reports on fights between bands of robbers.6 And that is precisely what they were.7 But because equipping ships was costly and princes wanted their share of the booty, many of those who participated in raids on the high seas were commissioned by or at least acted with the tacit assent of the princes of the mother countries. Even if these silent or even official partners in raids on the high seas thought the violent appropriation of wealth in every part of the world was par-ticularly desirable, they had to take account of the potential negative effects on their rule. In other words, robbing one’s European competitors had to bear at least the appearance of legitimacy. Just as on land, legitimacy for such raids was created by claiming territorial rights over parts of the seas. Much later the argument was put forward to do away with such claims because territorial rights over certain regions of the seas could not really be successfully defended. But that had not really been the point throughout the period in which such arguments were put forward as valid. For whosoever claimed territorial rights over an entire region of the sea gave himself the right to impound any ship found in the region without requiring the permission of whoever exercised sovereign jurisdiction over the vessel, to confiscate its cargo and to pass sentence on its crew as pirates. There was no court in which the legality of such a procedure could be challenged; therefore, the publication of a claim to the dominion over a certain part of the world seas included the claim to decide what was right and wrong in that territory. Letus start out by following, if only very roughly, the carving up of the world’s seas in territories. This began in 1493 when Columbus and his crew returned from their first major voyage. It had started the great race for wealth overseas. Initially, only the Crowns of Spain and Portugal seemed to have the prospect of competing successfully in this race. In order to not destabilise their rule in Europe, both powers turned to the Pope so that he could carve up the New World for them. The fact that the demarcation line chosen was changed again the following year shows clearly that negotiations prior to the conclusion of the treaty had been tough.8 Be that as it may, the ‘world’ outside Europe was split up between Spain and Portugal on 7 June 1494 under the aegis of Pope Alexander vi in the Treaty of Tordesillas. Whatever was to be found further than 370 nautical miles west of the Cape Verde Islands went to the Kingdom of Spain, while everything to the east of this imaginary line belonged to the Kingdom of Portugal. Since the end of the fifteenth century, the high sea between Europe and the Americas had thus been formally broken up into territories.9 To be precise, the Pope did not determine which part of the New World both kingdoms could rightly appropriate, but merely distributed territories in which they were allowed to do missionary work.10 Of course, this specific detail played no role in practice. Further demarcations followed. In 1526, the Treaty of Zaragoza established how the Pacific was split up. The so-called Moluccas antemeridian corresponded to today’s 135th meridian. It is possible that these lines kept Portuguese and Spanish ships from entering each other’s territories in the high seas, as laid down in the treaty, but for the French corsairs and English ‘discoverers’ sailing the seas for booty from the sixteenth century onwards, these treaties only consisted of a risk if they were defeated on the seas. To reduce this risk and thereby enhance their chances of getting a share of said booty, the rulers of the new sea powers challenged the legitimacy of the lines and demanded that their subjects should have the right to sail through the sea regions claimed by Portugal and Spain.n In Câteau-Cambrésis, negotiations were conducted for a peace treaty between Spain and France in 1559.12 It was said that there had been an additional, oral agreement amending the published text of the treaty. In any case, it was reported time and again that the peace treaty was limited to Europe and that armed conflicts beyond this ‘line of friendship’ would not be interpreted as a breach of the treaty. Although the issue of whether the treaty had this additional clause alongside the official version is still open to debate/3 it played a considerable role in academic debates over the past decades, triggered by a publication by Carl Schmitt in 1950, which in turn referred to a publication by Gustav Adolf Rein from 1930. According to Schmitt, bracketing out an area of combat outside Europe served war in Europe (1950, p. 66).14 More recent research on the treaty negotiations have shown that Spain offered to reduce its claim on territories, hitherto based on the Treaty of Tordesillas. But ultimately, Spain did not give up its claims (Kempe 2010, p. 57). They continued to apply to everyone who continued to run the risk of being attacked as pirates when violating the maritime territory to which Spain laid claim.”

But that had not really been the point throughout the period in which such arguments were put forward as valid. For whosoever claimed territorial rights over an entire region of the sea gave himself the right to impound any ship found in the region without requiring the permission of whoever exercised sovereign jurisdiction over the vessel, to confiscate its cargo and to pass sentence on its crew as pirates. There was no court in which the legality of such a procedure could be challenged; therefore, the publication of a claim to the dominion over a certain part of the world seas included the claim to decide what was right and wrong in that territory. Letus start out by following, if only very roughly, the carving up of the world’s seas in territories. This began in 1493 when Columbus and his crew returned from their first major voyage. It had started the great race for wealth overseas. Initially, only the Crowns of Spain and Portugal seemed to have the prospect of competing successfully in this race. In order to not destabilise their rule in Europe, both powers turned to the Pope so that he could carve up the New World for them. The fact that the demarcation line chosen was changed again the following year shows clearly that negotiations prior to the conclusion of the treaty had been tough.8 Be that as it may, the ‘world’ outside Europe was split up between Spain and Portugal on 7 June 1494 under the aegis of Pope Alexander vi in the Treaty of Tordesillas. Whatever was to be found further than 370 nautical miles west of the Cape Verde Islands went to the Kingdom of Spain, while everything to the east of this imaginary line belonged to the Kingdom of Portugal. Since the end of the fifteenth century, the high sea between Europe and the Americas had thus been formally broken up into territories.9 To be precise, the Pope did not determine which part of the New World both kingdoms could rightly appropriate, but merely distributed territories in which they were allowed to do missionary work.10 Of course, this specific detail played no role in practice. Further demarcations followed. In 1526, the Treaty of Zaragoza established how the Pacific was split up. The so-called Moluccas antemeridian corresponded to today’s 135th meridian. It is possible that these lines kept Portuguese and Spanish ships from entering each other’s territories in the high seas, as laid down in the treaty, but for the French corsairs and English ‘discoverers’ sailing the seas for booty from the sixteenth century onwards, these treaties only consisted of a risk if they were defeated on the seas. To reduce this risk and thereby enhance their chances of getting a share of said booty, the rulers of the new sea powers challenged the legitimacy of the lines and demanded that their subjects should have the right to sail through the sea regions claimed by Portugal and Spain.n In Câteau-Cambrésis, negotiations were conducted for a peace treaty between Spain and France in 1559.12 It was said that there had been an additional, oral agreement amending the published text of the treaty. In any case, it was reported time and again that the peace treaty was limited to Europe and that armed conflicts beyond this ‘line of friendship’ would not be interpreted as a breach of the treaty. Although the issue of whether the treaty had this additional clause alongside the official version is still open to debate/3 it played a considerable role in academic debates over the past decades, triggered by a publication by <redacted> Carl Schmitt (PERSON) </redacted> in 1950, which in turn referred to a publication by <redacted> Gustav Adolf Rein (PERSON) </redacted> from 1930. According to <redacted> Schmitt (PERSON) </redacted>, bracketing out an area of combat outside Europe served war in Europe (1950, p. 66).14 More recent research on the treaty negotiations have shown that Spain offered to reduce its claim on territories, hitherto based on the Treaty of Tordesillas. But ultimately, Spain did not give up its claims (Kempe 2010, p. 57). They continued to apply to everyone who continued to run the risk of being attacked as pirates when violating the maritime territory to which Spain laid claim.”

text: Reprhase and explain very thoroughly "I'm confident in saying that I or any of the people I know. Never had any intent or interest in the information being discussed. Any claims that someone gave me a phone to absolute. I repeat absolute fabrication. There's a story I've heard, and it goes that walls have ears too. In other words one had better be careful what one talks about. There is absolutely no logic in anyone claiming to have given me a phone. Because doing so puts not only me but the relevant law enforcement in a tricky situation. If there are such claims they are fabricated for a purpose. I have not had a single conversation with my ex's father. I did not initiate the topic of conversation. And if anyone has a recording of the conversation. You can clearly hear me utter the words "Don't talk about it, I don't trust you." I understand, however, that unfortunately in some people's eyes I look like the person who not only acted haughty with his girlfriend but inadvertently helped create a complicated situation. It is also an absolute lie to claim that the arrest was recruitment. In my opinion, with the technical means available, if anyone ever wanted to take information from anyone it was not me. Also vaccines were not only produced in the west. Any claims that this was a situation that would embarrass only western countries is, in my opinion, absolutely inaccurate. By now you could buy a phone from EE a hundred times and check if in any way those phones were any different to the others. In no way by my actions have I meant to damage the prestige, authority or compromise anyone. I have a degree in business and management, which is tantamount to working in administration."

text: After class, Jane met some of her friends for lunch. Anna asked, “Jane, didn’t you have baked potato and broccoli yesterday and the day before that too? Hey, you also have the same drink that you had the past couple of days. What is going on with that?” “Just after I was born I was diagnosed with a condition called phenylketonuria, or PKU for short,” replied Jane. “I don’t understand the condition very well. My parents made me follow a special diet the doctors gave them. My diet has very little of the amino acid phenylalanine. Some nutrients are missing in my diet so I drink a can of this nutrient drink every day. Caitlin, read the warning on the back of that diet soda you are drinking.” “Why would there be a warning on my diet soda can?” asked Caitlin. “Oh, here it is! It says, Phenylketonurics: Contains phenylalanine.” Jane replied, “If I have any of that stuff, I just can’t think straight. When I first got here, I went off my diet. It was awful. I couldn’t remember anything, I couldn’t concentrate, and I couldn’t pay attention. Biology was impossible when I was eating ‘normal’ foods. Now that I am back on my diet, biology is still a hard class, but it’s not as bad as when I was eating ‘normal’ foods.” Jane has to eat a diet with lots of fruits, vegetables, low protein breads, and pasta. No one else in her immediate family (parents, brother, and sister) have PKU. They can all eat ‘normal’ foods. Upon further investigation into her family history, she discovered that her dad’s sister has PKU also. If she has children with a man that is a carrier for PKU, what are the chances that their kids will be born with PKU?

text: write the following in professional tone using maximum 100 words: Stakeholder Collaboration: Experienced in effectively collaborating with stakeholders, including Sales Managers, Branch Managers, and RTOS, to ensure training programs are aligned with business operations. Conducted thorough evaluations of training programs to identify areas for improvement and provided recommendations to upper management for enhancing effectiveness. Assessed skill gaps among employees and developed targeted training courses to address identified needs, while also seeking to enhance existing resources and training strategies. An example of this in my previous position at Mainfreight, I was co- assisting in the design, implementation, and coordination of the Chain of Responsibility (CoR) tailored training program which was part of the Heavy Vehicle National Law (HVNL). This program aimed to ensure that all our drivers contractors, suppliers, and employees were fully aware of their responsibilities in the transportation of goods on the roads. Throughout this project, I maintained consistent engagement with the regulating body, the National Transport Commission (NTC), and collaborated extensively with Sales Managers, Customers, and Managers to ensure that the training programs aligned with project objectives and effectively incorporated any new changes or updates. This initiative significantly contributed to cost savings for the organization by ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements. Undertaking this project provided me with valuable exposure to strategic planning, accountability management, and standards of operations and policy analysis and development. Over the past five years, our primary focus has been on establishing a robust legislative and planning framework to mitigate the risk of financial penalties resulting from any non-compliance with new regulations. By ensuring that our employees were well-informed about these regulations, we aimed to prevent any breaches and subsequent financial losses.

text: write an article out of this press release: -- RELEASE EMBARGOED APRIL 28, 2023, AT 12 PM NOON-- Olympian clean seas activist Neil Agius attempts world-first open water swim. The 100 Mile Swim will be his greatest challenge yet. PALMA DE MALLORCA, SPAIN – On WEDNESDAY, April 27, 2023. Neil Agius, ultra-endurance athlete and world record holder, on Friday officially announced the 100 Mile Swim, a world-first record attempt in the longest non-stop, unassisted, current neutral, open water sea swim ever undertaken. The launch took place Friday, April 28, at 12:00 at the Palma International Boat Show & Superyacht Village, where Agius shared his vision for the challenge and his reasons for undertaking it. The 100 Mile Swim will see Agius attempt to swim from Mallorca around the west coast of Ibiza touching land on the eastern coast of Ibiza, covering approximately 160km, in open water. The swim will test Agius's endurance, strength, and mental resilience. A former Olympian and current world record holder in another category of swim, Agius is no stranger to pushing his limits. However, the 100 Mile Swim represents his most ambitious challenge yet. Speaking ahead of the launch, Agius said, "The 100 Mile Swim is not just about setting a world record. More importantly, it is about highlighting the problem of pollution and pollutants in the seas and oceans.” Media Contact: Ivan Martin <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS> <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_PHONE_NUMBER> The 100 Mile Swim will take place in the summer of 2023 during a brief weather window that begins at the end of June. Agius has been training intensively for months to prepare for the challenge. He is supported by a team of around 25 volunteers and professionals made up of medics, swim observers, navigators, skippers and crew, motivators, media, and a nutritionist, who will ensure that he remains safe and healthy throughout the swim. The launch of the 100 Mile Swim is expected to generate significant interest from the global media and supporters. Agius's previous successful world record attempts have been covered by major news outlets around the world, and the 100 Mile Swim is likely to attract even more attention. The swim will also raise awareness for ocean conservation and the urgent need to conserve our precious marine ecosystem, causes very close to Neil's heart. The 100 Mile swim is supported by the Mallorca Preservation Foundation as well as Neil's own NGO Wave of Change Malta, Ocibar Marinas and the Palma International Boat Show as well as being proudly sponsored by Atlas Insurance and Visit Malta. The Palma International Boat Show & Superyacht Village provides the perfect backdrop for the launch of the 100 Mile Swim. The event is one of the most prestigious boat shows in the world and attracts thousands of visitors each year. Agius will have the opportunity to speak to a global audience about his vision for the challenge and the impact he hopes it will have. The launch of the 100 Mile Swim is set to be a historic moment for endurance swimming and a significant milestone for Agius personally. With just a few months to go until the swim, Agius and his team are ready to take on this epic challenge and make history. Media Contact: Ivan Martin <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS> <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_PHONE_NUMBER> --- ENDS ---

text: first separate input: 'CHAPTER 1 INTRODUCTION In this chapter, we describe the research background with respect to hand kinematics analysis methods and state-of-art studies of hand and fingers tracking system, then we show the significance of researches for hand and fingers tracking technology in various fields (section 1.1). Next we state our research motivation (section 1.2), and we present overall contribution and innovations of the research (section 1.3). We finish up with the basic organization of the following of the thesis (section 1.4). 1.1 Research Background and Significance Recent researches have focused on developing hand and high-precision finger motion detection systems for a variety of applications based on tracking methods, such as robotics, virtual reality, and medicine Rehabilitation. Some of those applications are as follow: -Robotics: The most popular study field in robotics is the manufacture of prostherix hands. Researchers design prototype of an underactuated prosthetic hand, which improve the range of motion and dexterity of thumb and pinch and innovatively restore the capability of the thumb-index pinch [1]. -Virtual reality: Hand movement is the main means of interacting with the environment, so it is crucial in virtual reality (VR) applications. Although the existing inverse kinematics motion detection is sufficient for full body tracking (Fig.1.1) [2], it is difficult to locate small body parts such as fingers, and these parts are often blocked in the optical detection process. VR professionals need additional systems (such as inertial trackers) with low reliability [3]. -Medicine Rehabilitation: A 5-DOF hand rehabilitation robot is designed and developed using a synthetic method for generating natural curved finger tip motion using a 1-DOF mechanism (Fig.1.2). It’s practical in the diagnosis and treatment of hand injuries and diseases [4]. With the help of advanced sensors and computer vision methods, those system is able to capture and analyze finger movements. Machine learning algorithms are often used to interpret the data and provide real-time feedback to users [5,6] . These studies give us examples and inspires of the importance of hand-finger motion detection in different industries, and also show promise in improving the accuracy of the finger motion detection and tracking system. However, there are still challenges in developing a compact and comfortable system for users to wear and use for a long time, as well as its applicability in more application scenarios. 1.2 Motivation The existing research has done enough detail in measuring and tracking hand movements, and has derived many extensions and applications in various fields. However, the bending and extension of a single finger is different from the movement of the entire hand, and the detection of finger movement becomes very difficult when moving or rotating. In current finger motion detection technology, there are two distinct categories can be distinguished depending on the use of cameras or individual sensors. -Vision based: Use passive optical motion capture technology by setting cameras to capture the dynamic image of a specially designed glove with markers, then use the machine vision technique to process the images and correlate the local variation of image to the motion of fingers or change in the hand gesture [7,8]. The vision based hand tracking system has non-contact perception function, making hand motion detection convenient and efficient. Besides, machine vision and imaging analysis based on camara involve expensive components and complex algorithms [9], which are very expensive for ordinary users. The main advantage of a vision based system is its high tracking accuracy, but it has drawbacks such as sensitivity to light intensity fluctuations and occlusion issues, which may lead to tracking errors [10]. -Sensors based: The sensor-based systems directly detect the motion and bending of the fingers using various types of sensors such as accelerometers [4], gyroscopes, magnetic sensors, resistive sensors, and ElectroMyoGraphy (EMG) sensors [11] etc. To a certain it can help to mitigate the problem of vision-based system. Besides, the sensor-based systems are also in general more compact and inexpensive. However, acceleration or inertial sensors are generally susceptible to gravitational artifacts due to the rotation and vibration of arms or bodies. In our research, we intend to design and develop a magnetic sensors based device which is hihgly compact and have ability to detect finger motions real-time accurately. Because magnetic sensors have advantages over limitations of vision based systems which severely restricted the adoption of hand tracking in real-world applications (bulky tethered systems is impractical and line of sight or privacy concerns) [12]. Finger tips are significant marks of hand kinematics analysis, which have fewer amounts than joint angles of fingers and simpler structure. We intend to fix a magnetic sensor on each fingertips and a permanent magnet on the dorsal side of the hand to detect finger motions. Since the magnetic permeability of the human body is very similar to air, water and other non-ferromagnetic materials, it does not affect the static magnetic field [13]. The low-cost, compact, and accessible hand-finger motion tracking system is possible. 1.3 Contributions We propose a magnetic hand-finger motion tracking system which is simple, compact, low-cost, accurate and unobstructive for intelligent human-computer interface and various other applications involving hand gestures recognization. The core principle is relative fingertips position estimating with the use of magnetic sensors, then detect the hand gestures from the orientation and locations of the fingertips. The main contributions of our research are: 1. A intelligent finger motion tracking system using magnetic sensors is porposed. For sensors detecting part of the system, we choose the scheme that measure the orientations and locations of sensors in motion in a stationary magnetic field created by one permanent magnet. A permanent magnet is fixed on the dorsal side of the hand. Five 9-axis IMUs is settled on each of the fingertips, and one 6-axis IMU is fixed with the permanent magnet in order to achieve the attitude calibration and distance measurement between IMUs. After we get the result of finger motion by combining each 9-axis sensors’ orientations and locations (angular velocity on 3-axis, acceleration rate on 3-axis, and magnetic flux density on 3-axis), the next step is to adopt deep learning approaches to realize the real-time gesture recognization function. Various common gestures can be displayed as corresponding patterns when we make actual movements. 2. A set of algorithms for computing orientations and locations of sensors on the fingertips are proposed. First, we use EKF method for estimating the orientations of the 9-axis sensors on the fingertips to the 6-axis sensors on the dorsal side of the hand. After orthogonalization the coordinate system of two sensors through matrix operation, we apply L-M algorithm to calculate the linear distance between those two sensors to get the locations of 9-axis sensors. The L-M algorithm is based on a dipole model which approximate the magnet as a dipole under the research condition. Our experiments show the dipole model satisfied high approximation and accuracy within a certain range which is sufficient for finger motion tracking and gesture recognization. 3. A DNN method is adopted to achieve the real-time gesture recognization function. DNN map the features of existing spatial samples to another feature space through layer by layer feature mapping, in order to learn better feature representation for existing inputs. Firstly we maintain the posture of a specified gesture on the device and create positional data of the gesture in three-dimensional space through the movements and rotations of the hand and wrist. Then we cyclically group and train all data to obtain high accuracy in both training and testing sets. Finally, we use the wearable device to continuously make any gesture in the gesture library, the terminal can accurately display the corresponding gesture pattern. We develop our device prototype on a SBC: Raspberry pi 4b. It is also fixed on the dorsal side of hand aiming to read data and computing the orientations and locations of sensors. The data from 9-axis sensors are transmitted by I2C bus real-timely to the SBC for the next step of attitude calibration and distance calculation. Besides, we use our originally designed PCB to achieve improvements on stability and integration. Finally we fabricate prototype device on a left-hand glove, improve the compactness and comfort additionally. '

text: Is this overwrought: The disquiet of the three am bustle that only a hospital could generate, other infants crying in distress, machines sounding off alarms, paediatricians rushing to save the lives of fragile babies; Max barely registered it anymore. Lily was finally five months old , and possessing the strength and vitality of the median three month old child. “My bean is now a little cucumber.” he announced as he admired how far she’d progressed, as she unleashed a tiny giggle into the air. Max gave a hearty chuckle as his readjusted the squirming Lily in his lap. “Finally, we’re going home , all the way back to California. And Mr bear her gets the aisle seat , huh?” Max winked at Lily, her entire face enlightening with the promise of a jovial, healthy day, her pulse steady, her respiration clear and sparkling with life. "Laugh away bean, the sound is glorious, I bet it could actually cure some cancer, send some kids home" .

text: We had this dialogue: Me: What’s a legal status of MOTHER 3 in other countries except Japan? You: MOTHER 3 is a video game developed by Brownie Brown and HAL Laboratory, and published by Nintendo for the Game Boy Advance in 2006. Outside of Japan, MOTHER 3 has not been officially released or localized, which means there is no legal status for the game in countries other than Japan. However, fans have created unofficial translations and ROM hacks for the game, which may be illegal to download and play due to copyright infringement. It’s advised to check the respective copyright and gaming laws in specific countries before attempting to play any unofficial versions of MOTHER 3. “However, fans have created unofficial translations and ROM hacks for the game, which may be illegal to download and play due to copyright infringement” Me: Illegal only from point of view of the international right, but not national right of most of countries You: It is true that the legality of downloading and playing unofficial translations and ROM hacks of MOTHER 3 can vary depending on each country’s national laws and regulations. While international copyright law might consider these actions illegal, some countries might not enforce these laws to the same extent, or they might have different rules governing video game distribution and copyright. It is essential for individuals to understand their own country’s laws and regulations on this matter before deciding to engage with any unofficial versions of the game.

text: przetłumacz na poslki "When cargo arrives at the crossdocking location the Transportation Hub shall perform the following activities: • Perform required customs transit formalities. For detailed import / transit procedures please compare P0554.1 or P0554.2 • Check documents / report arrival of truck / container if required • Before unloading, secure that trailer or container is placed correctly at the loading-dock per safety instructions • Check the seal number and seal condition (if seal is required) and compare with relevant shipping documents. If seal number does not correspond with the seal number stated on the waybill, or if seal is incorrect, damaged, broken or lost this must be noted on the waybill. This is to be signed by the driver. • Break the seal • Unload the goods from truck or container. In case of insufficiently secured goods, o For internal SKF Hub: directly inform the shipping unit company transport o For external contracted hub: Inform contracting partner The purpose of this information is to improve the loading security. The information shall include photos of unsafe loading condition. • Handle Dangerous Goods according to specific valid rules and regulations."

If seal number does not correspond with the seal number stated on the waybill, or if seal is incorrect, damaged, broken or lost this must be noted on the waybill. This is to be signed by the driver. • Break the seal • Unload the goods from truck or container. In case of insufficiently secured goods, o For internal SKF Hub: directly inform the shipping unit company transport o For external contracted hub: Inform contracting partner The purpose of this information is to improve the loading security. The information shall include photos of unsafe loading condition. • Handle Dangerous Goods according to specific valid rules and regulations."

text: Coastal restoration and rehabilitation offer great promise for vulnerable and marginalized groups in need of adaptation. However in Kenya, a critical research gap in evidence-based policy discussions demands immediate attention to advance these efforts towards building resilience for the most vulnerable segments of society. Presently, there is a lack of a dedicated community-led framework and relevant indicators that can effectively align coastal restoration and rehabilitation initiatives with the priorities of different social groups, especially those who are vulnerable and marginalized, such as women, children, indigenous communities, persons with disabilities, and minorities, all residing within the coastal regions. Additionally, there is a pressing need to establish methods for measuring and reporting the effectiveness of these restoration and rehabilitation efforts in addressing the intersectional vulnerabilities within these communities. Furthermore, linking the lessons learned from these initiatives to national adaptation plans and NDCs (Nationally Determined Contributions) is essential for ensuring a comprehensive approach to coastal resilience and safeguarding the interests of the vulnerable populations. The project aims to co-create locally led restoration indicators with the established community of practices and all the stakeholders through development of evidence based policy labs. Our project main goals: 1. To map out all stakeholders and establish a community of practice in coastal conservation and restoration. 2. To assess Policy, Institutional Framework and Knowledge gaps on coastal ecosystem restoration initiatives. 3. To assess the locally led restoration activities undertaken by different community groups. 4. To work with different local community groups to co-develop and agree on indicators that capture priority restoration actions and their expectations of impacts based on the assessed gaps 5. Co-development of impact learning and conservation framework: Based on the assessments, we will develop learning materials on restoration and conservation of coastal ecosystems and a conservation framework that targets the specific needs of coastal communities. 6. Establishment of multi stakeholder policy labs that will target all stakeholders and community of practice implementing restoration programs. These will be trained on Locally led restoration metrics co-production and development
masked_text: Coastal restoration and rehabilitation offer great promise for vulnerable and marginalized groups in need of adaptation. However in Kenya, a critical research gap in evidence-based policy discussions demands immediate attention to advance these efforts towards building resilience for the most vulnerable segments of society. Presently, there is a lack of a dedicated community-led framework and relevant indicators that can effectively align coastal restoration and rehabilitation initiatives with the priorities of different social groups, especially those who are vulnerable and marginalized, such as women, children, indigenous communities, persons with disabilities, and minorities, all residing within the coastal regions. Additionally, there is a pressing need to establish methods for measuring and reporting the effectiveness of these restoration and rehabilitation efforts in addressing the intersectional vulnerabilities within these communities. Furthermore, linking the lessons learned from these initiatives to national adaptation plans and NDCs (Nationally Determined Contributions) is essential for ensuring a comprehensive approach to coastal resilience and safeguarding the interests of the vulnerable populations. The project aims to co-create locally led restoration indicators with the established community of practices and all the stakeholders through development of evidence based policy labs. Our project main goals: 1. To map out all stakeholders and establish a community of practice in coastal conservation and restoration. 2. To assess Policy, Institutional Framework and Knowledge gaps on coastal ecosystem restoration initiatives. 3. To assess the locally led restoration activities undertaken by different community groups. 4. To work with different local community groups to co-develop and agree on indicators that capture priority restoration actions and their expectations of impacts based on the assessed gaps 5. Co-development of impact learning and conservation framework: Based on the assessments, we will develop learning materials on restoration and conservation of coastal ecosystems and a conservation framework that targets the specific needs of coastal communities. 6. Establishment of multi stakeholder policy labs that will target all stakeholders and community of practice implementing restoration programs. These will be trained on Locally led restoration metrics co-production and development

text: summarise into bullet points: When I am emailed by pupils studying The Woman in Black for GCSE and A-level, many refer to it as "gothic", and indeed it forms part of a university course in gothic literature. But although the book has something in common with the pure gothic fiction of the 18th and 19th centuries, it is really only a distant cousin of the genre. It is a ghost story – not a horror story, not a thriller – and not a gothic novel; although the terms are often used very loosely, they are not by any means the same thing. I set out to write a ghost story in the classic 19th-century tradition, a full-length one. There have never been many, writers perhaps having felt the form would not stretch successfully. By the time I began mine, in the 1980s, full-length ghost stories seemed to have died out altogether. I read and studied the Jameses, Henry and MR, and Dickens, and I also had beside me the "bible" – Night Visitors by Julia Briggs (still the best study of the form). The list of ingredients included atmosphere, a ghost, a haunted house and other places, and weather. A footnote to "ghost" was a) of a human being; and b) with a purpose. There are dozens of little books of "true" ghost stories, usually sorted by geographical location, but almost without exception the ghosts have no purpose and so the stories are ultimately unsatisfying. A headless horseman rides by, a phantom coach clatters down a dark road, a veiled lady drifts up a staircase and through a wall, a pale and misty child's face is glimpsed at a window – and that is all. The ghosts are there and they apparently go through the same motions again and again. It is ultimately uninteresting. There has to be more to fiction than that. There also has to be more than an easy manipulation of the reader's superficial emotions – unless making someone jump out of their skin is the writer's only aim. Not that trying to induce a delicious thrill of fear is bad – it is another form of entertainment, and what is wrong with being an entertainer? Dickens certainly considered himself to be one. I knew my ghost story, like all my fiction, had to have a serious point and it was this that must sustain the length and underpin the sense of place, the creation of atmosphere and the events. But moral points come out of character, and I kept asking myself the question: "Why does a ghost return to this life?" Perhaps to give information that they have withheld in life – the whereabouts of a will, say, or the identity of a murderer, or to warn. But my ghost returns to exact revenge and it is the nature of revenge that it is never satisfied; and so, loss and grief lead the woman in black on, trying to exact revenge for her child's accidental death by causing those of others. She cannot let go, and her revenge is an evil that continues to be visited on Crythin Gifford. The grief and craving for revenge must be released or she cannot find resolution and peace on either side of the grave. So here was my central character. Why a "woman in black"? I must have had Wilkie Collins's The Woman in White in mind but it was more than 25 years since I had read his novel. Otherwise, I have no clear idea where she came from. Thomas Hardy believed that places are as important as people in fiction, because people are formed by the landscapes in which they are born and bred, though that is probably less true now than it was in his day, when, especially in rural areas, they tended to remain rooted in one place. But a harsh climate and a hard landscape toughen people. A low-lying, dank place tends to be lowering to the spirits, and we all know that constant wind drives people mad. I think the pathetic fallacy is less fallacious than is often supposed. I don't know where the plot of the book came from, partly because I never do know, partly because it is too long ago. But I remember one thing. In the early 1970s I worked by the sea, behind which were the marshes. Walking there at dusk, the light making the gleam and the low wind rattle the reeds, was when I began to think seriously about ghosts. It seemed natural to adopt a rather formal style and that came along with the point of view. I had to write in the first person. The narrator, Arthur Kipps, is the living key to the book, just as the woman in black is the dead one.

text: edit: Despite the increasing importance of digital transformation in healthcare systems, the path towards the digital transformation of hospitals still presents some problems(Raimo et al., 2023), in such a way that most digital transformation projects have not lived up to expectations (Preko and Boateng, 2020). In this regard, Agarwal et al. (2010) found that health care improvements related to digital transformation often fail to materialize. A recent systematic literature review conducted by Marques and Ferreira (2020) highlighted a sharp increase in the last twenty years of studies on the topic of digital transformation in healthcare originations such as hospitals. However, the authors highlighted that these studies focused mainly on specific issues such as integrated management, medical images, electronic medical records and virtual services. The contributions that dealt with the digital transformation of hospitals from a broader perspective focused mainly on the identification of the different digital technologies implemented, on the advantages and benefits deriving from the implementation of digital technologies and on the barriers and challenges associated with the implementation of these technologies (Tortorella et al., 2020a). However, there is an important gap in the academic literature since only a limited number of studies have examined the drivers capable of influencing the level of digital transformation of hospitals, so empirical research on the drivers of digital transformation of hospitals is still lacking (Raimo et al., 2023; Kraus et al., 2021b).

text: Please re write this technology newsletter to make it read better. The audience is prospective technology candidates who we'd like to come and work at our company: Welcome to the latest version of the CommBank Technology Newsletter. As a member of our Talent Community this newsletter is your exclusive insight into news, events and happenings across CommBank Technology teams. We're expanding our Gen AI partnership with Microsoft We will work with Microsoft to drive greater customer benefits through wider adoption of generative AI (Gen AI) and ongoing cyber security initiatives. Key elements of the partnership include delivering: • Superior customer experiences – including developing a CommBank Copilot to resolve customer queries faster and help customers better understand their money; • Customer safety – sharing intelligence to enhance cyber security and developing tools for CBA business customers to help them better protect themselves; • Sovereign capability – working together to develop cyber skills capability to help Australia keep pace globally on artificial intelligence; • People experience – developing Copilots to help team members use Generative AI to better respond to customer needs; • Engineering excellence – increasing collaboration between engineering teams through AI to share knowledge and solutions to deliver more for customers. We hosted our first post Covid meet-up! The event included a panel discussion on the hot topic of generative AI. Our expert panel explored: ◾ The implementation of generative AI at scale ◾ Creating personalised customer experiences ◾ Scaling trusted AI for growth and productivity We rolled out our industry leading NameCheck technology to other major financial institutions Bendigo Bank and fraud monitoring company Satori, are each looking to pilot our industry leading NameCheck technology in a bid to further protect Australians from scams and mistaken payments. Since its launch in March this year, the technology has prevented more than 10,000 scam payments which would have totalled in excess of an estimated $38 million and already reduced mistaken payments by more than $100 million We launched an AWS 'CloudUp for Her' skills development program With 1200 women registering to take part in the first course it was the largest cohort that AWS has seen in the APAC region for a similar program. The course is open to all women employed within CommBank and it doesn't require any technology skills. It will help us tackle the technology talent shortage particularly amongst females by investing in skills for the future.

text: You are an excellent writer and expert in writing. Write an academic cover letter email to Sir/Madam and include my skills and enthusiasm for the funding position in their department. The GA position is as below: "Position Summary The Graduate Assistant – Fitness and Wellness will coordinate, with the Assistant Director of Fitness & Wellness, programming, scheduling, evaluating, and project planning relevant to Campus Recreation and departmental objectives, also aligning with the Graduate Assistant’s curriculum and experiential goals. Supervisor Reports to the Assistant Director of Campus Recreation – Fitness and Wellness Essential Functions 1. Coordinate Campus Recreation wellness and fitness programs, including advertisement, registration, scheduling, and program evaluation. 2. Assist with recruitment, hiring, supervision, and evaluating of group exercise (BearFit) instructors, personal trainers and fitness attendants. 3. Provide practical training and regular meetings, both group and one-on-one, with BearFit group fitness instructors, personal trainers, and fitness attendants. 4. Prepare contracts and provide prompt payment to wellness instructors at the conclusion of sessions. 5. Maintain complete and accurate organized records for Campus Recreation wellness and fitness programs including contracts, licenses and credentialing, attendance logs, statistics, and other related documents. 6. Coordinate, with the assistance of the Assistant Director – Fitness and Wellness, personal training appointments, daily schedule monitoring and follow-up, communication with trainers, including providing the utmost customer service to patrons. 7. Evaluate and maintain personal training assessment space and three studio operations for customer service, member experience, and risk management. 8. Maintain inventory of supplies and equipment for the Foster Recreation Center fitness and wellness areas. 9. Support the Assistant Director – Fitness and Wellness with set-up of special events as needed. 10. Assist with other duties assigned. Other Responsibilities 1. Assist with special projects and assignments as requested. 2. Attend all required meetings: division and department-wide. 3. Serve on internal and University committees, as needed. Education, Experience and Skills Required 1. Must meet all requirements outlined by the graduate assistant contract. 2. Experience with fitness and wellness programs including, but not limited to, personal training and group exercise, is preferred. 3. American Red Cross CPR/AED/First Aid certification is preferred and is obtainable through Campus Recreation upon the start of this graduate assistant position. 4. Good communication, customer service, organization, and leadership skills. 5. Required to work up to 20 hours per week. 6. Reports to work two weeks prior to" My information: "My name is <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_PERSON>, and I am thrilled to share that I have been admitted to the MASLA TESOL program at MSU for the upcoming fall semester of 2024. My BA is English Language Translation. The opportunity to further my education at MSU, a university renowned for its commitment to academic excellence and a supportive community, instills a great sense of excitement and anticipation in me as I look forward to contributing to and benefiting from this esteemed institution. Furthermore, I would like to highlight that my TOEFL scores, with a 28 in both the written and speaking sections, underscore my proficiency in English. I’m confident that this, along with my strong data analysis skills, and familiarity with Excel and SPSS, make me a suitable candidate for the GA position. My resume, which I have attached to this email, provides further details about my academic background and professional experiences."

text: Ledbury Poetry (UK) has announced that Donegal poet Annemarie Ní Churreáin is among the poets shortlisted for the fourth Ledbury Hellens Poetry Prize for best second collection published in Britain or Ireland in 2021 or 2022. The prize aims to support and encourage poets at the mid-career stage, with a prize of £5000 for the winning second collection. Speaking of Ní Churreáin’s nominated work, judges Togara Muzanenhamo and Penelope Shuttle said: “Drawing inspiration from the concept of restorative justice – Annemarie Ní Churreáin’s The Poison Glen entwines legend from the Gaeltacht landscape with moments from history to depict the systematic mistreatment of unmarried or abandoned mothers and the children born to these women. Ní Churreáin revisits locations of state care institutions in Ireland over the past hundred years and beyond with an inquisitive lens that requires us to ask what the left-behind sites remember or what sense of the child remains after trauma. The Poison Glen stands as a literary monument to silenced voices”. ADVERTISEMENT - CONTINUE READING BELOW Originally from Cloich Cheann Fhaola, Ní Churreáin's books include Bloodroot, Doire Press, 2017, Town, The Salvage Press, 2018, and The Poison Glen, The Gallery Press, 2021. She is a recipient of the Irish Arts Council’s Next Generation Artist Award and a co-recipient of The Markievicz Award. She is Poetry Editor at The Stinging Fly Magazine. Her most recent literary project, a limited edition poetry pamphlet titled Ghostgirl, explores the Stranorlar Workhouse and Stranorlar County Home, also known as Stranorlar Mother and Baby Home. The project was a commission of the Donegal Archives Service as part of the Donegal Decade of Centenaries Programme. Co-judge Togara Muzanenhamo said: “The award is particularly special because it celebrates the accomplishment of what can be an artistic hurdle for some poets – compiling a second collection. There are numerous prizes for first collections and best collections but few focus on the pivotal role of a poets’ second book – a book that may highlight a poet’s maturing voice or solidify their career. I am excited at the prospect of reading work that will confidently explore and freely navigate language and introduce us to voices that will shape the future of poetry”. ADVERTISEMENT - CONTINUE READING BELOW The other collections and poets shortlisted for the prize are; Kaveh Akbar (Chatto) Pilgrim Bell; All the Names Given, Raymond Antrobus (Picador); A Blood Condition, Kayo Chingonyi (Chatto); England’s Green, Zaffar Kunial (Faber); Bloom, Sarah Westcott (Pavilion Poetry). The winner of the fourth Ledbury Hellens Poetry Prize will be announced on December 4 at 7pm at an online prize giving ceremony hosted by the Ledbury Centre.

Such a question like “Are you clear?” does not require the recipient to answer, but is adopted to confirm the differences of the identity and status of the operator and the recipient, positioning the recipient in the identity of the “suspected offender” who should make a truthful confes￾sion. The party with greater power in the conversation is usually the initiator of the turn, who can control the content and interrupt the other party. People in communication achieve their specific communicative purpose by choosing discourse resources and give meaning to the linguistic symbol according to the purpose in the process of communication. The purpose is closely linked to institutional power, and the realization of purpose is closely related to power as well. The operator constructs his “police” identity through discoursal practice and obtains the power entitled by the law, thereby achieving the purposes of obtaining information and defrauding money (see examples 13 and 14). text: Rewrite and improve this paragraph, adding examples that are very meaningful to children: Running your own cotton candy stand is no joke. Ralph, the enterprising owner of Ralph's Fairy Floss, just stress ate three bags of the stuff: he's got a big decision to make about the price of his cotton candy. The outcome of Ralph's decision will depend not only on the actions he takes but also on the actions of his only competitor, Regina. Both Ralph and Regina have two choices: lower their prices or keep their prices the same. Ralph would like to choose the action that will maximize his profits. But given the interdependencies of each competitor's actions, this decision is not so easy. Enter game theory, the formal study of decision-making in situations where one player's outcome depends on other players' decisions.

text: Structure and optimize the following focus plan: Background: Aly has been with Amazon for 12 months, He joined VF team in July of 22’’ as city manager for West Cairo shortly before PEAK and showed high ownership and bias for action and was rated as an HV2. Shortly after PEAK, and starting in Jan 23’’, Aly faced a few health-related family issues that started to clearly affect his focus, performance and output. He requested multiple personal leaves, and the team offered support to cover for him. After things seemingly started to get better on the personal aspects, his performance never picked up, rather, it continued to slack. Performance Assessment: As a City manager Aly is responsible for all West Cairo sites, 5 of which are critical- high volume VF sites with Amazon AAs on ground. Aly is tasked with all on ground operations, IB control, stock control, AA performance, TPH, labor management and their development for all of his sites. On ground Ops: Aly has not been fully present on ground for the past couple of months and has been relying more on the on-ground supervisor to control operations hence multiple issues are not being identified on time and handled properly. In addition, a few instances occurred where even when he was present on ground he failed (or chose not to) to communicate high risk impactful issues to his superiors, pears or relevant stakeholders which led to tons of extra work on the team’s end and at times translated to actual misses impacting overall team metrics and performance. IB and stock Control: Continuous gaps have been found in both areas with multiple promises of remediation on his end with no appropriate output. Issues have not been brought to leadership attention on time, because of vague, incomplete or untrue answers to follow-up questions which resulted in a significant trust breach between Aly and the team. AA performance and TPH: Due to his lack of presence on ground, TPH has been dropping from its BAU value and AA’s performance has been slacking. Multiple instances occurred where items were poorly packed, lost, shipped without AWBs, etc.. A clear lack of control, follow up and proper training has been identified and communicated to Aly without proper actions taken on his end to fix it. Initial Performance Assessment Conclusion: Aly’s continuous drop in performance and irresponsiveness to feedback, along with serious concerns on earning trust has led the team to decide on putting him on focus to communicate the gaps more assertively and track performance progress very closely. Task, goals and actions should be communicated to him in details, with clear milestones, deliverables and deadlines in order to assess his progress properly. Development Areas; 1- Work on earning back team’s trust by communicating more clearly and truthfully in a timely manner. 2- Take back control of on ground ops, by being more present and DDing into all matters in question. 3- Work on better tracking AA’s performance & TPH, identify gaps and work in depth to develop and train AAs and optimize TPH. 4- Keep track of data and volumes to better manage and communicate labor needs, and optimize rooster. 5- Work on his communication skills with the team and relevant stakeholders to be able to callout critical issues on time. 6- Work on better understanding priorities, criticalities and time sensitivity of his tasks.
